text: Blinds closed. Dust motes in the air. A large GOLDFISH TA bubbles. BRANCH RICKEY at his desk. Two photos on the wal Abe Lincoln & Leo Durocher. CHALKBOARDS covered with 100' OF NAMES, every player in the Dodger organization. CLYDE SUKEFORTH and HAROLD PARROTT sit across from Rickey who stares at them. Sukeforth stares back. Parrott nervou
Gentlemen, I have a plan... As of now, only the Board of Directors and my family know. Sukeforth and Parrott exchange a look.
A plan's always good, Mr. Rickey. And you always got one.
My wife says I'm too old, That my health isn't up to it. My son says that every one in baseball will be against me. But I'm going to do it. Parrott looks to Sukeforth who keeps his eyes on Rickey.
Do what, Mr. Rickey?
I'm going to bring a Negro ballplayer to the Brooklyn Dodgers.

With all due respect, sir, have you lost your mind? Imagine the abuse you'll take from the newspapers alone. Never mind how it'll play on Flatbush. Please, Mr. Rickey. Rickey looks dismissively at Parrott, over to Sukeforth. PINK REV 4-19-12 1A.
There's no law against it, Clyde.
There's a code. Break a law and get away with it, some people think you're smart. Break an unwritten law though, you'll be an outcast. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 2.
So be it. New York is full of Negro baseball fans; every dollar is green. I don't know who he is, or where he is, but he's coming.

The big Birmingham Black Barons CATCHER behind the plate Kansas City Monarchs JOHN SCOTT stands at bat. The catche attention on the RUNNER DANCING off first. Stomping a foo feinting, hard to see clearly in the glare of the lights.

Where'd you learn to move like that, runner?! At dime a dance night?! Stay quiet! INSERT: Birmingham, Alabama. April 8, 1945.  On the first pitch the runner takes off. The catcher fire second. See it from his POV as the runner slides in aSAFE A foot on the bag, the runner dusts off, heckles the catc
Is that the best you got?! Huh?! I'm going to steal nine, ten bases today! You better start counting! The catcher frowns. Standing, we see he is a big, big man
Where's your shortstop from?
California.
He's got a mouth on him. Shaking his head, the catcher gets back in his crouch, signals the PITCHER. On the wind-up, the Runner is off again. The catcher fires to THIRD: aSafe!a
You got a rag arm, catcher!
Steal home! You'll find out what kind of arm I got! DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 3.
Okay, I'm coming! The Catcher looks over at Scott who chuckles.
California, huh?

Well California here he goes, if he comes down here. The Catcher gets back down in his squat. Signals the pitcher: fastball. Scott digs in, ready. The runner danci off third. Here comes the wind-up... The Runner takes off even as the pitcher fires it in. The Birmingham Catcher receives it. As the Runner slides -- The Catcher intentionally drives his glove, the ball and hands into the runner's face -- WHALLOP! Sound drops as we're knocked flat senseless along with the runner. ON HIM now as he tries to push himself up from the dirt. close look at JACK ROOSEVELT ROBINSON. A born battler, he shakes out the cobwebs, finally lurches to his feet, look the UMPIRE. He never heard the call.

What was I? The umpire passes one hand over the other: Safe. Jack loo over at the catcher, gives him a pointed look as he goes The catcher shoves him in the back. Jack turns, shoves ba As the two men wrestles each other to the ground --
Rickey and Sukeforth going through stacks of FILES on the desk. A black ballplayer's picture is clipped to each. As Rickey reviews one, Sukeforth tries to hand him another.
Josh Gibson. Oh boy can he hit.
No.
No? Rickey won't take the file; the answer is no.  DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 4.
Alright. Roy Campanella. Sukeforth holds it out; Rickey won't take it.
A heck of a player. But too sweet, they'll eat him alive.
(holds up file)  Satchel Paige then. Parrott enters carrying an armful of files.
Too old. We need a man with a future not a past.  (holds up his own
Here. Jack Roosevelt Robinson.  As Parrott sets them on the desk, they start to slide off spilling to the floor. Helpless to stem the tide, Parrott looks down, surrounded by black faces...
(flips through file) A four sport college man, out of UCLA. That means he's played with white boys.
Twenty-six years old, now with the Kansas City Monarchs. Batting over 350 even as we speak. 350! And he  was a commissioned army officer!
He was court-martialed. A trouble maker. He argues with umpires. A quick temper is his reputation. Rickey is obviously keen on him.
What was he court-martialed for?
For refusing to sit in the back of  a military bus.  (checks the file)  Ft. Hood, Texas. The driver asked  him to move back. The MPs had to  take him off.  DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 5.
Do you see?
I see he resents segregation. If  he were white, we'd call it spirit!
If he were white, sir, we wouldn't  be looking for him. Rickey ends the debate...
Robinson's a Methodist. I'm a  Methodist. God's a Methodist. We  can't go wrong. Find him. Bring him  here.

A BLOODHOUND watches as a BUS pulls into a SERVICE STATIO the tires RING the bell hose. A million miles easy on thi road rumbler. The BANNER reads: KC Monarchs. Insert: Interstate 24, Missouri - August 24, 1945. The DRIVER steps off. The fellas follow, getting off to stretch their legs. Hot and tired. A WHITE ATTENDANT saunters out. The driver steps over to meet him.
Fill her up?
Yes, sir. The attendant starts unscrewing caps on two 50-GALLON TAN
Where you all headed?
Chicago. As the attendant shoves down a pump, starts filling, Jack steps off. He spots and heads for a restroom. White Men Only lettered on the door. The attendant roused as he see
Hey! Where you going, boy!? BLUE REV 4-07-12 6. Everyone looking over as Jack stops.
I'm going to the toilet.
Shit, boy, c'mon. You know you can't go in there. Jack does a slow burn, then suddenly strides toward the attendant. The air rife with tension.
Take that hose out of the tank.
Huh?
Take it out. We'll get our ninety- nine gallons of gas someplace else. The attendant blinks. He takes a look from Jack to up and down the deserted highway. No business in sight.
Okay, use it. But don't stay in there too long. Jack heads back. The Driver, the players, a bit stunned.

Jack splashes water on his face, rips a paper towels from dispenser, pats his face dry. He balls the wad up, squeez it in his fist before firing it into the trash. He consid his reflection in the mirror. As he regards himself, we h the SERVICE BELL ring outside.
A car has pulled up. The driver talks to several players. They look over as Jack exits. The driver is Clyde Sukefor
Are you Jackie Robinson?

Blinds closed. Jack sits across the desk from Rickey. Sukeforth sits a little further back. Rickey is staring a Jack. Bushy eyebrows flared, light gleams off his glasses INSERT: August 28, 1945. Brooklyn.  Jack doesn't know what to do, looks to Sukeforth. Finally
Do you have a girl?
Excuse me?
A man needs a family relying on him. It insures he'll behave responsibly. Do you have a girl?
I think so.
You think so? Jack looks to Sukeforth who smiles placidly. Back to Rick WHITE 3-14-12 8.
I don't make much money. Between the army and now baseball I've been away a lot. And Rae, Rachel, she wants to finish school. Considering all that, I say I think so.
Do you love her? Rachel?
Don't you know?
Yes, sir, very much.
Marry her. What? Rickey stands, walks to a window. Jack looks at Sukeforth who raises a hand as if to say: Give it a chanc

Baseball's a hard life; a man needs a good woman by his side. You don't want the only person waiting for you at home to be a catcher. Sukeforth chuckles at that. Rickey fingers open a slat on the blind and peers out. Jack looks hard at him.
Coach Sukeforth here said you were starting a new Negro League. That doesn't make sense to me.
It doesn't, huh? Are you calling us liars, Jack?
What's this about, Mr. Rickey?
This is about baseball. Rickey opens the shade. Sunlight floods in. Rickey follow it to the chalkboard, to the list of players under Montre

I see you starting in the spring with our affiliate in Montreal. If you make it there, we'll try you down here with the Dodgers. The white Brooklyn Dodgers. Jack looks to Sukeforth who nods: Yes, you heard right. BLUE REV 4-07-12 9.
I'll pay you $600 a month and a $3,500 bonus when you sign the contract. Is that agreeable? Believe it or not that's a lot of money to Jack on this d in time. This is all becoming a bit overwhelming.
Yes, sir. That's fine.
There is one condition. I have a pile of scouting reports. I know you can hit behind the runner, that you can read a pitch. The question is can you control your temper?
My temper?
Yes your temper! Are you deaf?!  Rickey furious, the avuncular old man gone. Jack sits the fists now balled. Rickey to Sukeforth like he's not there
He looks proud. Willful.
He'll need to be. Rickey looks back to Jack who is as angry as he is confus
I want to win! I want ballplayers who can win! Are you one of them?!
Yes.
A black man in white baseball. Imagine the reaction. The vitriol. Rickey strides forward, gets in his face.
The Dodgers check into a hotel. A decent good hotel. You're worn out from the road and some clerk won't give you the pen to sign in.
We got no room, boy, not even down in the coal bin where you belong. BLUE REV 4-07-12 10. Jack looks like he wants to tear Rickey apart.
The team stops at a restaurant. The waiter won't take your order. (adopts a new voice) Didn't you see the sign on the door? No animals allowed.
What are you going to do then? Fight him? Ruin all my plans? Answer me, you black sonofabitch!
Do you want a ballplayer who doesn't have the guts to fight back? Is that what you want?

I want one who has the guts not to fight back! There are people who will not like this. They will do anything to get you to react. If you echo a curse with a curse, they will only hear yours. Follow a blow with a blow and they will say a Negro lost his temper; that the Negro does not belong. Your enemy will be out in force, but you can not meet him on his own low ground. We win with hitting, running and fielding, nothing else. We win if the world is convinced of two things: that you are a fine gentlemen and a great ballplayer. Like our Savior, you must have the guts to turn the other cheek. Jack considers Rickey. Rickey looks worn out.
Can you do it? Jack poised at what will be his Rubicon. He crosses.
Mr. Rickey, you give me a uniform, you give me a number on my back, and I'll give you the guts.
A phone RINGS on a table. RACHEL ISUM steps in, 23, possessed of style that you can only be graced with.
Hello?
Jack in a PHONE BOOTH, the lobby busy beyond.
Rae, I'm in Brooklyn.
Brooklyn? For what?
I don't want to say on the phone. In fact, I'm not supposed to tell anyone. She can hear the tingle in his voice.
Jack?
I'm here, Rae
What's going on? You're supposed  to be playing in Chicago?

We've been tested you and me. Our  loyalty, our faith. We've done  everything the right way. Me  trying to make money. You  finishing school. Separated by the  war, now by baseball. We don't owe  the world a thing. Only each other.  She's actually getting a little scared now.
Jack, what are you talking about? What happened? GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 12.
The Brooklyn Dodgers just signed me to play ball up in Montreal. It might lead to bigger things. To something wonderful.
What does it mean? For you and me?
Rae. Will you marry me?
Absolutely. When?
Now.
Jack, I don't think we can get married in a phone booth.
Jack rounds a corner in a TUXEDO, the bow tie undone. Rac follows in her WEDDING GOWN. They look beautiful.
Did my mom look happy?
Yes. They reach the door. Jack gets out a key to unlock it.  Rachel looks nervous, steps back across the hall.
Did my gram look happy?  Swinging the door open, he looks at her. The air charged.
Everyone looked happy. I've never seen so many people looking happy. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 12A.
Did Jack Robinson look happy?
What if I can't make you happy? He steps over, aware of her shyness.
Too late. You already do. It's  you and me, Rae.
Until the wheels fall off.
The world is waiting for us.
It can wait one more night
Are you coming, Mrs. Robinson?
(kisses him back)  I'd follow you anywhere, Mr.  Robinson.  He picks her up, carries her over the threshold. As the d clicks shut behind them...
The shades closed; we're scheming again. WENDELL SMITH si across from Rickey who stares back intently. Bespectacled 32, Smith covers baseball for the Pittsburgh Courier.
Who's the best shortstop you ever saw?
Rabbit Tavener.
Rabbit Tavener? And you call yourself a sports writer? WHITE 3-14-12 13.
Yes, a sentimental one. I'm from Detroit. He was the Tiger shortstop when I was a boy. How about you? Who's your best?
Pop Lloyd.
Not Honus Wagner?
Wagner is number two. And Rabbit Tavener would not break my top 25. Where do you suppose Jackie Robinson will end up on that list?
He won't break it. He doesn't have a shortstop's arm. Robinson belongs on second base.
Alright then, where would he rate at second?
If he was playing now he'd be the best second baseman in the majors.
High praise. He'll have to be the best in the minor leagues first.
What are you saying, Mr. Rickey?
I'm saying it's going to be a very interesting spring training. A lot of players are coming back from the war and with gas rationing over, we can train down in Florida again.
Daytona Beach?
You're aware in the past six months a black boy was lynched in Madison, Florida and a black man down in Live Oaks?
Those towns may as well be a million miles from Daytona. WHITE 3-14-12 14.
Live Oaks is 150 actually.
I spoke to the Daytona mayor. He assures me there'll be no trouble. But Rickey doesn't sound so sure. They consider each othe
Mr. Smith, are you a Communist?
I'm a Democrat. Why do you ask?
I have a business proposition. What's your salary at the Courier?
Fifty dollars a week.

I will pay you an additional fifty dollars a week plus expenses if you will attend spring training with Jackie Robinson. You will watch over him, help him to avoid the harm that could come if he were to do or say anything out of turn. You will act as his chauffeur, you will secure accommodations for him wherever the team may be, help him find restaurants, etc...
What's in it for me? Besides the fifty dollars and a whole lot of aggravation?
Unprecedented access for any reportage you feel appropriate. What do you say, Mr. Smith?
I say yes, sir. If a Negro is good enough to stop a Nazi bullet in France; he's good enough to stop a line drive at Yankee Stadium.
Ebbets Field actually, but yes, I agree. The world is ready.
Over 500 guests: journalists, players and politicians all listen politely as a SPEECH drones to an end. INSERT: New York City. 23rd Annual Baseball Writer's Association Dinner February 3, 1946.

As our former President Herbert Hoover remarked in his tribute to our national pastime: a The rigid voluntary rules of right and wrong, as applied in baseball, are second only to religion in strengthening the morals of the American people.' Polite applause as the speaker steps off. The clapping mo enthusiastic as the lights dim on all but an impromptu se plantation house columns. Hoots as a BUTLER appears weari satin knee breeches and a MONTREAL ROYALS jersey. He hold ring like a lawn jockey, a WHITE MAN in BLACK FACE. The laughs get louder as he peers out with exaggerated wide e
Lordy, lordy, it's looking like da massa will be late dis ebning. As the LAUGHS from the audience subside, a sportswriter dressed as a COLONEL enters from stage right.
Robbie! Robbie!
Yassuh, Massa Kunl. Here Ah is. Huge LAUGHS as he struts and dances his way over. WHITE 3-14-12 16.
Jackie, you woolly headed rascal. How long yo' been in the family?
Ebber since Massa Rickey done bots me from da Kansas City Monarchs.
(aside to audience) Rickey that no good carpetbagger! What could he be thinking! Huge LAUGHS from that one. Two people enjoying it we'll recognize later as HERB PENNOCK and BOB COOKE.
Ah came near bein' killed last night, Kunl.
How's that, Jackie boy?
Ah was comin' up a dark street and three men was behind me. And they tried to do me with a baseball bat.
You don't say?
Yes, suh. Ah recognized one of dem. Ah'm gonna hab him arrested.
But I thought you said it was dark?
It was. But I know he played for the Philadelphia Baseball Club. On account of he struck at me three times and never hit me once. That brings the house down. Check out their laughing face
A gleaming American Airlines DC-3 angled up on the tarmac PASSENGERS climb the portable stairs and disappear inside INSERT: February 28, 1946. Burbank, California
Jack and Rachel are being seen off by FRIENDS from the wedding and his mother MALLIE. Jack is in a natty suit wi Rachel in a beautiful coat.
You knock the cover off that ball.
I will, Mama. Mallie hugs Jack and then kisses Rachel.
Look after each other.
We will. She reaches in her bag, brings out a cardboard SHOEBOX; i ever so slightly greasy at the bottom.
Take this. It's chicken.
They have food on the plane, Mama.
You never know what might happen. I don't want you getting there starving and too weak to hit. Rachel gives Jack a subtle but emphatic look: No.
Jack escorts Rachel to the plane, the shoebox in hand.
I couldn't tell her no.
I know she means well; I just don't want to be seen eating chicken out of a box like some country bumpkin. Jack runs his hand over her coat.
No one's going to mistake you for a bumpkin in this. PINK REV 4-19-12 18.
Well, they'll know I belong on that plane or wherever I happen to be.
Descending toward a runway. Landing gear coming down.

A WOMAN exits the lady's room, passing a SIGN: White Only REVERSE to show Rachel looking at it like she's been slap Jack joins Rae from the TICKET COUNTER, with the chicken INSERT: New Orleans Lakefront Airport.
The flight to Pensacola leaves in an hour... You okay?
I've just never seen one before.
(follows her look) We're not in Pasadena anymore. A sudden momentum carries her forward.
Honey... Rae -- He takes a step after her, stops as she disappears inside Jack unsure what to do. He looks around. Looks back. He  doesn't need this right now.
A black BUSBOY reacts as a bickering Jack and Rachel ente
I promised Mr. Rickey we'd stay out  of trouble.
Did you promise him we wouldn't go  to the bathroom? You've done it.
Before I promised.
It was just a toilet. You'd think  the commodes were made of gold.  The busboy watches as Jack and Rachel slide into a booth. Jack reaches for a MENU, here comes the COOK.
You folks can't sit here.
Excuse me?
It's white only. Jack looking to Rachel; it's equanimity time. Not easy.
I'll sell you some sandwiches. But you gotta take a em to go. Jack looks to the busboy, back to the cook.
No. You hang onto those. Mastering himself, Jack slides out. Drilling the cook wit look, he offers his hand to Rachel as she slides out as w
Seen from on high. Jack and Rachel, sitting on a bench, t little figures as passengers move along the concourse. Th sit a bit apart from each other, the world a wedge.
SMOKE PINWHEELS as the wheels of a BOEING 247 touch down. INSERT: Pensacola, Florida. Later that day.
Jack and Rachel worn out among eight other passengers. As the door is opened, FOUR of the eight get up and disembar After a beat, FOUR NEW PASSENGERS board and take their se
Just a hop to Daytona now. As Rachel nods, an AIRLINE EMPLOYEE boards, MISS BISHOP. makes her way over. She spots who she's looking for.
Jack Robinson? Come with me. She starts away without explaining, looks back at them a impatiently.
Come on now. Both of you.
The shoe box sitting on the counter, Jack in mid discussi with Miss Bishop. Rachel just behind Jack.
We have to lighten the plane. There's some bad weather east of here. A heavy plane's dangerous.
Tell her you're with the Dodgers.  Jack would rather not play that card.
When's the next flight?
Tomorrow morning. But it's booked. So someone'll have to cancel. Jack and Rachel unaware as a WHITE COUPLE are ushered out door and onto the tarmac behind them.
Look, I'm with the Brooklyn Dodger organization. I've got to get down to Daytona. I'm supposed to report to spring training in the morning.
We'll do our best to get you down there by tomorrow afternoon, but it might be the day after.
He follows her gaze to where the white couple get on the plane they got off. Jack wheels on Miss Bishop, furious.
You gave away our seats! Get us back on that plane! Miss Bishop picks up a PHONE, holds it in Jack's face.
Do you want to call the Sheriff? Or should I?

Closed. A line of EMPTY BUSES; the BANNER on one: Daytona Beach. Across from it Rachel sits at one end of a BENCH, fur pulled around her. Jack at the other, staring off int the night. Finally, he reaches down, picks up the shoebox He pulls out a DRUMSTICK, considers it, then takes a bite
Mama knew... He holds it out to Rachel. She slides over, takes it, tak a bite as well, smiles at him. He smiles back.
It's good.
LEO DUROCHER hitting fungoes. One after the next. PEE WEE REESE and EDDIE STANKY both settle under the same ball.
I got it! I got it! I got it! I got it! They both back off at the last second and it drops to the ground between them. Durocher chuckles.
That's what spring training's for, boys! Sort out our differences! He hits another. This time to the outfield where veteran DIXIE WALKER gives chase, finally gives up on it.
C'mon, Dixie, get after it!
I'm old!
I'm gonna squeeze one more year out of that worn out body of yours!
If you could, skipper, my wife would sure appreciate it!
Keeping the women happy! That's what it's all about! BLUE REV 4-07-12 23.

Rickey drives a dirt road through the training field sing aTwo Sleepy Peoplea along with the radio: Passing BROOKLY DODGERS, MONTREAL ROYALS & ST. PAUL SAINTS on either side Durocher hits another as Rickey pulls up.
How are they looking, Leo?

Rusty, Mr. Rickey. But we'll get a em oiled up and ready in no time. You find your lost sheep yet? Troubled, Rickey shakes his head a no'. As he does, Harol Parrot hurries over. He's the Dodgers travelling secretar
Jackie Robinson's on a bus leaving Pensacola.
A bus? Harold, how in blazes did he end up on a bus?! BOB BRAGAN, in his catching gear, passing by with pitcher RALPH BRANCA and KIRBY HIGBE. Higbe asides to Bragan:
Why don't they just put him on a  watermelon truck?
What's the matter with you guys?
Not a thing, Branca, but we ain't just two pretty faces either.

Wendell Smith stands waiting as a BUS pulls in. The big air brakes hiss. The doors open and the PASSENGER disembark. First a DOZEN WHITE FACES, then a DOZEN BLACK. Last but not least, Rachel and Jack. They look exhausted.
Jackie Robinson... Mr. Rickey sent me to meet you. Wendell Smith. Pittsburgh Courier. I'm going to be your Boswell. BLUE REV 4-07-12 24.
My who?
Your chronicler, your advance man. Hell, even your chauffeur. (tips his hat) Mrs. Robinson.
It's Rachel.
Man, you two look wiped out.
You got a car? Get us out of here.
Jack and Smith carry the luggage. Smith's excited being  around Jack even if he is grumpy. As Smith unlocks the  Buick, Rachel considers a segregated pair of water founta
You ever been down South before, Rachel?
First time. We have our problems in Pasadena, but not like this.
Mr. Rickey says we follow the law. If Jim Crow and the state of Florida say Negroes do this and that, then we do this and that.
My life's changing right in front of me. Who I am, who I think I am.
Black neighborhood. The Buick stops at a nice looking hou
Joe and Duff Harris live here. He gets out the black vote, does a lot of good for colored folks.
Mr. Rickey set it up himself.
If we can't put the Robinsons in the hotels, they should stay some- place that represents something. Jack and Rachel exchange a look, the place seems nice.

Brooklyn plays downtown; Montreal a  few blocks from here. You'll stay with the Harrises except for a few  days at the end of the week. The  whole Dodger organization is going to Sanford, about 45 minute away.  You'll stay here though, Rachel.
Where are the other wives staying?
There are no other wives. You're the only one Mr. Rickey allowed to spring training. As the HARRISES step out on the porch, wave hello...
MRS. HARRIS leads Jack and Rachel up the stairs to a door the top. Mrs. Harris opens it.
I call this the love nest. I hope you like it.
I'm sure. Thank you. As Jack enters, Mrs. Harris starts back down.
Dinner's at five. Rachel enters, closes the door behind her --
-- And accidentally knocks Jack onto the bed. She lands o top of him. The room is impossibly small. It barely holds their luggage and the BED they're on. As they look around
It's a joke, right? GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 26.
I like it. The love nest. She kisses him. He's starting to like it, too.
Remind me dinner's at five.
I'll try to remember... As the kisses become more urgent...
Smith pulls up alongside the team buses, looks across at who is just a little nervous.
The first day of Spring Training.  My Pittsburgh Courier readers need  to know how it feels.
It's okay.
That's not exactly a headline.
That's all I got.
Look, Jack, right now it's just me  asking you. But you get on that  field and it's going to be the New  York Times and the Sporting News.  You should think about it.
If they ask something, I'll answer.

Alright, but you know when you're  at the plate, you want to feel like  you see the pitch come in slow?  Well, you want to see the questions  come in slow, too.  Jack just looks at him. Gets out. Smith sighs.  GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 26A.

As PLAYERS (Brooklyn, St. Paul & Montreal) warm up, pract Rickey sits on the bench, angry as he reads a NEWSPAPER. Harold Parrott hurries over, something urgent on his mind Rickey on a rant; Parrott can't get a word in.
Listen to this, Harold. Whenever I hear a white man - yours truly - broadcasting what a Moses he is to the Negro race, then I know the latter needs a bodyguard. (Parrott tries to

It is those of the carpetbagger stripe of the white race - me again - who under the guise of helping, in truth are using the Negro for their own selfish interest, thereby retarding the race! Parrott tries to interrupt again, but Rickey is furious.
The minor league commissioner of baseball said that! I pay part of his salary! You wouldn't stab me in the back like this, would you?
He's here, Mr. Rickey. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 27.
Why didn't you say so?!

Jack crossing toward them in his Montreal Monarchs unifor carrying a glove and a bat. 200 white players clocking hi He's surrounded by REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS. It's the for most of the batting and fielding and chatter among th Dodgers, Royals and Saints to come to a stop. Higbe forgets Bragan is throwing him a ball. It clocks hi in the chest. Reese and Stanky passing a medicine ball.
That's him, huh?
Take a wild guess. Flash bulbs go off in Jack's face. Questions like punches Shouts of a Jackie' and then...
Jackie, do you think you can make it with these white boys? Jack looks off to where Smith watches, back to the report See the questions slow. He answers with measure.
Sure, I had no problem with white men in the service or at UCLA.
What'll you do if one of these pitchers throws at your head?
(thinks a beat)  I'll duck. That gets some laughs.
Jack, what's your natural position?
I've been playing shortstop.
Are you after Pee Wee Reese's job? GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 27A. Jack looks over to where Reese watches with Stanky.
Reese plays for Brooklyn. I'm  worried about making Montreal.
Is this about politics?
It's about getting paid. Jack doing beautifully.  Smith breathes a sigh of relief...  YELLOW REV 4-24-12 28.
In a Montreal uniform, Hopper's too old to be a ballplaye He stands with Dixie Walker the Dodger right fielder.
Well, when Mr. Rickey picks one, he sure picks a black one.
He's fine with me, so long as you keep him up in Montreal.
Here comes the old man to save him. They watch as Rickey pulls Jack from the press. He leads Jack directly toward Hopper. As Walker excuses himself...
Good luck, Hop...
Clay, I'd like you to meet Jackie Robinson. Jackie, Clay Hopper, manager of the Montreal Royals. Hopper shakes his hand as they exchange greetings.
We ain't doing much today. Just throwing the ball around and hitting a few. Why don't you toss a few with those fellas over there?
Hey, Jorgensen! A kid in a Montreal uniform looks over. SPIDER JORGENSEN.
Meet Jackie Robinson.

The end of the day. Buses leave by team, the Dodgers and farm clubs. White faces look down as they pass a tired Ja who walks through the lot toward Wendell Smith and his Bu Higbe and Bragan call out from the door of the Dodger bus
Hey, Rook! Did you hear about the redneck shortstop? GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 29.
He thought the last two words of the National Anthem were Play Ball! Jack forces a smile, but the joke comes off a bit harsh. they seem like they're laughing at him as...
How about the shortstop making all the errors, tried to kill himself by jumping out on the highway?

A bus just missed him. Drove right between his legs! As the bus passes by, Jack sees the impassive faces of Di Walker, Reiser, Stanky, Pee Wee Reese and finally 20-year Branca. Branca smiles, offers an awkward little wave.
Between his legs, good one. He  must've read a joke book. If he  can read.  Jack just gets in the car. Smith sighs, drum rolls the ho of the Buick.
Hi, Wendell, how are you...? Well,  looks like I got a long drive to  Sanford.
MR. BROCK comes out the screen door carrying a tray of ta drinks. He sets them on a table, watches and waits as Smi and Jack get out of the Buick, start up the steps.
Jackie, I'm Ray Brock. Welcome to Sanford Florida! The day belongs to decent minded people. They shake hands. Brock looks to Smith, obviously knows h
Wendell, good to see you.

My wife's inside cooking. You know what she asked me this morning? She asked me, what do you serve when a hero's coming for dinner? WHITE 3-14-12 30. Jack's humble, embarrassed, doesn't know what to say.
I'm just a ballplayer, Mr. Brock.
Tell that to all the little colored boys playing baseball in Florida today. You're a hero to them. The look on Jack's face says that's a heavy burden.
Sit down, have something to drink. My special rum and coke.
No thank you, sir, I don't drink.
A ballplayer who doesn't drink? That's a new one on me.
I'll have one. I'm a stereotypical reporter through and through.
Mr. Brock, do you have a desk? I'd like to get a letter to my wife.
Of course, this way. As Mr. Brock leads Jack ahead, Smith sips his drink.
Rickey and Montreal manager Hopper stand by the dugout watching a spring game versus St Paul. Jack's playing second. They watch him closely as they talk.
He's getting by on a quick release, but his arm's too weak for short. Second base is his spot.
I agree. And I'll state another obvious, Clay, I need the players to act like gentlemen around him.
Uh huh. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 31. The MAN on first takes a lead.
To treat him as they would any other teammate.
Uh huh.

To be natural, to impose no restrictions on themselves. To all work together in harmony. WHACK! The hit & run is on. The man on first runs on the pitch as a LOW LINE DRIVE shoots for the gap between 1st 2nd. Robinson turns himself inside out to dive on his bel and catch it before it hits the ground. He spins himself around, pivots on a knee to throw the ru out before he can get back to first. A  Rickey is astound
That was superhuman.
Superhuman? Don't get carried away, Mr. Rickey, that's still a Nigger out there. Rickey takes a moment to process. It's Hopper's light admonishing tone that really halts him. Finally...

Clay, I realize that attitude is part of your heritage; that you practically nursed race prejudice at your mother's breast, so I will let it pass. But I will add this: you can manage Robinson fairly and correctly or you can be unemployed. They both look over as Jack comes off the field toward th
Attaboy, Jackie! Way to turn two!
Smith and Mr. Brock are sitting on the porch sipping rum cokes. A quiet evening. DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 32.
I hope Jackie sleeps alright. Chasing baseballs in the sun all day, I'd be in my grave. How are they treating him out there? They watch as a CAR slows, parks across the street.
Okay as far as I can see. A MIDDLE-AGED WHITE MAN, LUTHER exits the car and starts  toward them.
You find good people every place you go. Even here in Florida...
Is he in there?
Who is it you're looking for?
Nigra ball player. The air suddenly alive with danger.
He's asleep. Maybe you better come back in the morning.

I ain't comin' back. Other fellas is comin'. They ain't too happy about him stayin' here in Sanford. Playin' ball with white boys. (a long beat) Skedaddle, that's what I'd do. If'n they get here, and he's still here, there's gonna be trouble. He turns and walks away. As they watch, a phone rings...
Yes, Wendell, what is it?
Rickey in his pajamas in his hotel room. On the phone. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 33.

I see... Yes, I understand. Wake him up and get him out of there. Put him in the car and start driving for Daytona Beach. Now. And, Wendell, under no circumstance tell him what this is about. I do not want him to get it in his head to stay there and fight.
Half dressed, Jack sits on the edge of his bed, feeling b Through his open door, across a hall, we can see Smith in room. Passing in and out of view packing his own things.
I was just getting loose. Smith sticks his head in the door.
Don't just sit there. Pack your duds. We're blowin'. A phone RINGS somewhere. They hear Brock answer, then:
Wendell?! Smith leaves the room. Hold on Jack, despair as he listen

Yes, Mr. Rickey, I'm with him now... We're pulling out for Daytona in five minutes, soon as he gets his bag packed... Yes, yes, it's just one of those things. a One of those things.' As Jack's head hangs a little low

The street deserted, sidewalks rolled up. Jack angry and silent in the passenger seat. Smith jumpy behind the whee They stop as a PICK-UP stops ahead outside a BAR where: A DOZEN WHITE MEN in shirtsleeves exchange words with the boys in the truck. To Jack it looks like a typical small town bull session. To Smith it looks like something else. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 34. The white men look over at the two black men. One steps over, motions: roll down the window.
I wonder what he wants?
To run us out of town.
What are you talking about?  The man close now. As Jack cranks down the window, Smith  floors it. The Buick SCREECHES away, SWERVING around a CA coming the other way.
What the hell, Wendell?!
Man came by while you were asleep.
Told us more men were coming. Maybe  those boys. Mr. Rickey said to get  you to Daytona Beach a-s-a-p.
Why didn't you say so?
Mr. Rickey was afraid you wouldn't leave, that you would fight. As it becomes clear, Jack starts to LAUGH.
What the hell are you laughing at?
I thought you woke me because I was cut from the team. Jack LAUGHS harder. Wendell LAUGHS as well. As it fades, Jack looks back over his shoulder. Jesus...

A stadium SIGN boasts Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Montreal Royal PINK REV 4-19-12 35. Daytona Beach's black community is turning out to see Jac Robinson. Hundreds of people line up, mass at the: Colore Entrance. In their Sunday best. Families. Couples. The old. The frail. Young boys chase after each other. One MOTHER stands on her toes to spot her son.
Ed! You stay where I can see you! 13-year old ED CHARLES turns, waves his baseball glove ov his head so she can see him. Then to no one in particular
I'm thirteen years old. WHITE PEOPLE enter at several gates around them.
He sits watching as the segregated bleachers in right fil with BLACK FANS. All else is white. Rickey pops a PEANUT his mouth, confides to someone alongside him we don't see

I've spoken to the mayor. I've explained how much money we'll spend in Daytona. But still, when this fine young Negro man steps on that field today, he and the Dodgers will technically be breaking the law. A law which says white and black players cannot enjoy the same field at the same time. Does that make sense to you? Does Jim Crow make any sense when placed against the words of the United States Constitution? When placed against the word of God? POP OUT to reveal he sits beside the DODGER BATBOY, so sh his feet don't touch the ground. Rickey offers his peanut bag. As the batboy takes one...
I'll tell you, it does not make sense to me.

Jack swinging two bats to get loose. Watches as the Montr BATTER hits a LINE DRIVE which -- Pee Wee Reese nearly le out of his socks to bring down. Wow... As the CROWD claps in appreciation, Jack takes a deep bre

Now batting the second baseman -- Jackie Robinson! Jack wincing as he steps forward to both cheers and boos the white sections. As a a go home, coon' drifts over -- BIG OVATION from the black section in right drowns it out
Rachel sits with Smith. They react to some of the INVECTI coming from the white section.
Jack's got a thick skin. He'll be  okay.
How about you?
I better get one in a hurry.
Higbe watching from the mound as Jack steps into the batt box. Two well wishing voices from the infield stands.
Come on, black boy, you can make the grade!

They're giving you a chance! Do something about it! Jack heartened at the words. Concentrates as Higbe's firs pitch is fired. High and tight, Jack jerks out of the way YELLOW REV 4-24-12 37. Bragan, behind the plate, chucks the ball back, grins up Jack who does not look down at him as he settles back in.
The 13-year-old holding his hands together in prayer.
Please, God, let Jackie show them what we can do.
Here comes the next pitch. Even tighter. Jack nearly hit.

Ball two! Jack glaring, crowds the plate more. Bragan shows 1, taps his right thigh signalling outside. Jack watches it sail, doesn't bite. The umpire: aBall Three!a Higbe's fun slipping away as he can't find the strike zone.
Come on, Rook! Ain't you gonna swing at something?! Jack takes a practice swing, waits as Bragan sets up righ over the plate. Here comes the pitch. Low. aBall four!a
A big, over-reacting CHEER from the Colored section.
It's just a walk.
Who can blame them?
Looks ill-tempered over to first where Jack gives the sam look back as he sidesteps an enormous, defiant lead off t bag. Higbe incredulous. Did he just do that?

Well throw over there for crying out loud! Higbe fires to LAVAGETTO at first. Jack dives back in tim YELLOW REV 4-24-12 38. Higbe gets the ball back, settles. Jack takes a lead, but modest one this time. Here come the pitch -- And Jack goe You knew he was fast; but not this fast. Bragan's throw t Pee Wee is late and high. Pee Wee throws back to Higbe.  Higbe sets. Bragan gives him a sign. Jack takes a lead. O the wind-up, Jack goes. Bragan stands -- it's a PITCH OUT Bragan fires to third and Jack is caught in a RUN DOWN. I seems like half the team gets involved with Higbe finally getting the ball by third and Jack ducking under the tag. Safe! A BUZZ goes through the stadium now as people start realize they are not watching something or someone ordina
Watching from a seat behind third.
Thataway, Jackie! Thataway!
Higbe looks home for the sign, Jack dancing off third,  pounding his right foot toward home. He feints hard home. Higbe steps off the rubber. Jack stays where he is.

Hell! You're supposed to go back to third when I step off! Don't you know nothing?! He throws over. Jack back to the bag. Higbe gets the ball back, looks in. Jack bouncing, pounding off third. His  movements carry violence within them. Like a piston  exploding in an engine.  Higbe into his motion, stops his delivery, accidentally d the ball to the ground. The umpire signals BALK, points J home. Higbe is furious.
CHEERING, joyous. His mother joins in, happy despite...
I don't understand. What happened?
It's a balk, Mama. The pitcher can't start toward home and then stop. Jackie scores. GREEN REV 4-27-12 39.
But he didn't do anything.
Oh, mama, yes he did, he discombobulated the man.
Durocher looks to Branca, impressed.
He didn't come to play; he came to kill. Durocher starts out to the mound to talk to Higbe.
Watching from right field, the black crowd still cheering He walks over toward the open bullpen where Casey stands.
This really how it's gonna be some day? Baseball?

Montreal vs. Indianapolis. THE STANDS are half filled. Th COLORED SECTION is packed solid, accentuated by the many empty seats in the sections on either side of it. INSERT: De Land, Florida. No score, top of the first as -- Jack drops a BUNT down t line. The FIRST BASEMAN fields, throw to the SECOND BASEM covering. Too late. Only Jack doesn't stop. Realizing the SHORTSTOP isn't covering the bag, Jack bolt for second. The second baseman has to wait on the throw a when he makes it -- The UMPIRE signals safe. A bunt doubl Spider Jorgensen settles in the batter's box. The pitch. Crack, Jorgensen laces a single to left. Jack motors to third where Sukeforth is WAVING him home. We're with him at hip level as he tears down the basepath The CATCHER bracing for the throw - they COLLIDE - he's S As Jack gets to his feet, however, a Jim Crow POLICEMAN s up to meet him, grabs him by the shoulder.
Git offa this field now! WHITE 3-14-12 40.
What!? Why?

It's against the law is why. No niggers don't play with no white boys. Git off or go to jail. Jack shrugs the policeman's hand off his shoulder. That sends him reaching for his nightstick and -- Sukeforth is there to get between them.
You swing that thing you better hit me between the eyes with it.
Is that so? The CROWD BOOING. The black section especially.
(arrives from dugout) Hey, hold on, what'd he do wrong?
We ain't havin' Nigras mix with white boys in this town. Ya'll ain't up-states now; they gotta stay separate. Brooklyn Dodgers ain't changing our way of living. Where are you all from anyhow?
Greenwood, Mississippi.
Hell, man, you oughta know better. (a dangerous beat) Now tell your Nigra I said to git. You think I'm foolin'? Hopper looks desperately to Jack who just stands there.
What did you do?
Jack and Rachel out walking. He's been telling the story. PINK REV 4-19-12 41.
I said okay, Skipper, tell him... Ah'm a-gittin'. Sho'nuff, ah is.
You didn't?
I did. Then I took a long shower. We lost 2 to 1. She takes a few exaggerated steps to amuse him.
Ah'm a-gittin', ah'm a gittin'. He laughs, takes her hand. He's going to kiss her.
You're not getting away from me.
Jack... A white man bee-lines them from across the street, looks a real CRACKER. Jack on guard, gets in front of Rachel.
Get back, Rae. Go back. Cracker stops square across from him. Jack's fists balled
I want you to know something.
Yeah, what's that?

I want you to know I'm pulling for you to make good. And a lot of folks here feel the same way. If a man's got the goods, he deserves a fair chance. That's all. (tips his hat) Ma'am. As Cracker walks away... Rachel takes Jack's hand.
Rickey leans against his car watching a GROUNDSKEEPER pus mow the infield grass. Jack, in street clothes, joins him
You wanted to see me, Mr. Rickey? Rickey nods, consider the field a moment.
Bermuda grass grows so well here. I wish we could get it to grow like this in Brooklyn.
I like the way it smells when they mow it. PINK REV 4-19-12 42.
Me, too.  Rickey consider the field a moment, then Jack.

Jackie, it's my pleasure to tell you that you've earned a spot on the Montreal Royals. When they head north Tuesday for opening day against Jersey City, you'll be on the train. Jack trying to hold down his excitement.
I won't let you down.
I know that.
If you don't mind, I've got to go tell my wife.
Give her my regards. Jack about to head off when he looks back..
Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?

I'm an opportunist. With you and the Negro players I hope to bring up next year I'll put together a team that can win the World Series. And the World Series means money. Jack studies him a beat, not quite buying it.
Don't you believe that?
I don't think what I believe is important. Only what I do.
Agreed. Therefore, run the bases  like the Devil himself.
Worry those pitchers so they come apart. Sometimes they'll catch you, but don't worry about that. Ty Cobb got caught plenty. Just run as you see fit. Put the natural fear of God into them.

Ed Charles and his TWO FRIENDS follow Jack and the Montre PLAYERS as they walk toward the TRAIN waiting on the trac Jack is one of the last to board. He's almost through the door when something stops him. He looks back at Ed. A beat. Ed slowly raises his hand and waves. Jack smiles, does the same, then disappears inside. The WHISTLE blows the train starts out of the station. On impulse Ed starts trot out after it. Staying close. His friends follow.

The train picks up speed. The boys start to run. Arms pumping, feet flying. One boy drops off. Then the other. But Ed still runs. Chasing after that train carrying Jack Robinson. Finally, he stops, heaving for breath, watching the train disappear around the bend. A lonely beat. Then Ed gets down on his hands and knees. He sets his ear on t rail, closes his eyes. A thrum comes off the rail. A huge smile spreads. He straightens, shouts back to his friends
From somewhere, as the National Anthem ends...
INSERT: April 18, 1946 - Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City. Opening day of the International League Season. A COLOR GUARD march away to REVEAL:
30,000 FANS pack a stadium built for 24,500. Bunting and flags everywhere. 1000s of black fans are here (segregate only financially in New Jersey).
Jack steps up to some BOOING, but much more APPLAUSE. He looks ready to beat the world. INSERT: First inning.
Come on, Jackie, this fella can't pitch! Speaking of the pitch, here it comes. Jack tops a WEAK GROUNDER to short. As he's thrown out by a mile...
Sitting up off third. His knees knocked together to hold TYPEWRITER on his lap. Nothing to write about there. He looks over at Rachel who puts her hand over her mouth.
You okay?
I think I might be sick.
Excuse me, Wendell. He watches as she starts out, looks to the field.
I'd be sick at a swing like that, too.
Rachel exits looking stricken. She steps over, splashes a little water from the sink up into her face. An OLDER BLA WOMAN watches sympathetically.
Are you alright, honey?
I'm sick. I don't know why. The older woman rolls off a piece of paper towel for her.
Thank you.
When did you have your monthly last? WHITE 3-14-12 45. Rachel looks over, taken aback. But then...
I'm late.
It may be that you're pregnant. The older woman offers a little smile, leaves her there. INSERT: Third Inning.
Now batting. Jackie Robinson.
Jack steps up to bat. The JERSEY CITY GIANT PITCHER looks the Montreal RUNNER at first, glances over his shoulder a the Montreal RUNNER at second, then focuses on home.
His hands resting on the top of his typewriter.
Come on, Jackie. Come on, batter.
Emerging up the runway. The field opening up before her. There's Jack standing down there. The sight of him settle her. As she puts a hand gently over her belly...
Grimaces for something extra as he fires a high fastball Jack UNLOADS. All heads turn to watch it sail -- high int the left field bleachers, banging hard off the scoreboard
Nearly drops his typewriter, pushes his hat back as he watches Jack start his home run trot. Smith laughs. Joy.
Hopper can't believe his eyes. Softly to himself:
I'll be damned... WHITE 3-14-12 46.
As he runs the base paths. Over it, a TYPEWRITER CLATTERS
Robinson jogged around the bases, his heart singing... The crowd loves it as he continues toward third where Sukeforth is clapping for all he's worth.
And our own hearts beat just a bit faster, and the thrill ran through us like champagne bubbles...
Watching him head for home, shaking hands with the two me batted in. Pride & joy in her eyes.
Oh, Jack... Oh Jack...
Suddenly in pain, face beaded in sweat.
Jack! Jack! INSERT: November 18, 1946. Pasadena, California. She is in labor and we are in Huntington Memorial Hospita A CRY. The DOCTOR holds up a slick, wailing NEWBORN.
It's a boy. As Rachel holds out her arms for him...
Jack at the glass looking at JACKIE JR. Jack's eyes shine he regards his infant son. It's quiet. Jack's voice soft.
My daddy left. He left us flat in Cairo, Georgia. I was only six months older than you are now. I don't remember him. Nothing good, nothing bad. Nothing.
But you're going to remember me. And I am going to be with you until the day I die. The stakes just got raised...
THIRTY prominent BROOKLYN NEGRO leaders, representing a c section of civic responsibility, sit on folding chairs be a dais where HERBERT MILLER making an introduction.
As all of us know a young Negro second baseman played north of the border last season... INSERT: Brooklyn YMCA. February 5, 1947. In back: TWO DEACONS in the back whisper over a SPORTS PA
Look here what he did.
Led the International League in batting: .349, in stolen bases: 40, runs scored: 113. Plus batted .400 in the Minor League World Series.
Last season doesn't matter. The International League, it doesn't matter. What matters is this year. What matters is Brooklyn.
Shhh... Here he comes. As Herbert Miller introduces...
I present the general manager of the Brooklyn Dodger baseball club, Mr. Branch Rickey! Warm APPLAUSE as Rickey steps up. As it settles...
Good evening. I have something very important to talk with you about tonight. Something that will require courage from all of us.
I have a ballplayer on my Montreal team named Jackie Robinson. The start of applause. Rickey motions for it to stop. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 48.

He may stay there or he may be brought to Brooklyn. But if Jackie does come up to the Dodgers, the biggest threat to his success, the one enemy most likely to ruin that success, is the Negro people themselves! There is shocked silence in the room. Rickey notices a gr of KIDS watching from a raised running track, soldiers on

I say it as cruelly as I can to make you all realize the weight of responsibility that is not only on myself and the Dodgers, but on Negroes everywhere. For on the day Jackie enters the National League, if he does, I have no doubt every one of you will form parades and welcoming committees. You'll strut. You'll wear badges. You'll hold Jackie Robinson days and Jackie Robinson nights. You'll get drunk, fight and be arrested. This is too much. People are slackjawed. Rickey powers on

You'll wine and dine him until he is fat and futile. You'll symbolize his importance into a national comedy and yes, a tragedy! So let me tell you this! (pounds his fist) If any group or segment of Negro society uses the advancement of Jackie Robinson in baseball as a triumph of race over race, I will regret the day I ever signed him to a contract, and I will personally see that baseball is never so abused and misrepresented again! Is he done? An embarrassed smattering of applause. Mostly shock and stares. As Rickey stands there uncomfortably...
Rickey stands waiting; giving that speech has worn him ou The door opens and Miller looks in on him. WHITE 3-14-12 49.
I question your bedside manner, Mr. Rickey, but they've agreed to set up a committee of self-policing. We'll call it the 'Don't Spoil Jackie's Chances' campaign.
Thank you, Mr. Miller. I'm sorry; the spotlight will be on us all.

The silhouette of stately palms through the window. A PHO RINGS. A figure fumbles through silk sheets for the receiver. It's LEO DUROCHER, a WOMEN in bed alongside him INSERT: Beverly Hills. February 16, 1947.
Yeah?
Hello, Leo, what are you doing?
I'm bowling. Wait, I'm snowshoeing in the Alps. I'm trying to sleep, Mr. Rickey. It's still dark out.
It's very early in New York. Rickey on the phone.
Another spring training is upon us. In Panama. I need to know your attitude toward Jackie Robinson.
I don't got an attitude toward him. The girl rolls over to look at him. She is the actress LORRAINE DAY and she is stunning. As Durocher regards her
Eight times in the Bible we're told to love our neighbor. It's one of God's most repeated commands. PINK REV 4-19-12 50. She puts her hands on him. (Durocher addressing Rickey.)
Hi...
I don't know much about the Bible.
Me neither...
But I didn't go to school just to  eat my lunch either. I'll play an elephant if he can help us win. To  make room for him, I'll send my own brother home if he's not as good.
(in his ear)  What are you going to do with me?
We're playing for money, Mr. Rickey. Winning's the only thing that matters. Is he a nice guy?
If by nice you mean soft, no, not particularly.
Good. He can't afford to be. Nice guys finish last.
What about nice girls?  She starts to kiss him. It's hard to concentrate.
So you have no objections to him?
None whatsoever. Can I go back to sleep now?
Yes. Oh -- and Leo?
What? PINK REV 4-19-12 50A.
The Bible says a thing or two about adultery as well.
I'm sure it's got a lot to say about a lot. Good night. Durocher hangs up the phone, looks to her.
What am I gonna do with you?
Leo, I thought you knew...  As she kisses him...

Jack stands out front kissing Jackie Jr. good-bye as a CA muscles his LUGGAGE down the walkway to a waiting TAXI. J kisses Mallie and hands off the baby. Mallie carries the inside leaving Jack and Rachel alone to say goodbye. BLUE REV 4-07-12 51.
Promise me you'll write.
When did I ever not write?
I want you to know I'm there for you. Even if it's words on paper. He's sees she's raw, takes her in his arms with the baby.
Rae, you're in my heart. She sighs, rests her head on his shoulder.
You're getting close now. The closer you get, the worse they'll be. Don't let them get to you.
I will not. God built me to last. He kisses her. She kisses him back.
See you in Brooklyn in eight weeks.
It might be Montreal. A certainty grips her. She passes it on to him.
It's going to be Brooklyn. I know it is. Power in her words. He nods, looks off toward the taxi.

I've got to go, Rae.  She nods. They kiss, embrace a last time. He starts away  down the walk. She watches. Something not quite right.  A tug as Jack stops, looks back at her. Fighting back her emotion and then impelled forward, she runs to him. They  come together. She practically disappears in his arms. Th do not want to be apart.
Durocher eats heartily. Rickey's food is untouched.
It's a pipe dream, Mr. Rickey.
Pipe dream? What do you mean by pipe dream? INSERT: Panama City, Panama. March 18, 1947.
I mean it ain't gonna happen. The Dodgers are never gonna demand Robinson be brought up from Montreal. Ball players are conservative.
A team full of tough war veterans? Immigrants' sons? Boys from impoverished parts of the country?
It - ain't - gonna - happen.
You really believe they won't accept him? Once they see how he plays, how he can help them win.

I'm not saying they won't accept him: I'm saying they won't ask for him. I'm saying Robinson's good medicine, but they're not gonna like the taste. I'm saying bend over, boys, and get ready, this one might hurt a little.
Boy, this is good fish.
As Higbe (South Carolina) finishes WRITING something on a piece of hotel STATIONARY, Bragan (Alabama) looks to Dixi Walker (Alabama) and Dodger pitcher HUGH CASEY (Georgia).
Why do you think Rickey's got us playing spring games in Panama?
He wants to get us used to Negro crowds. He wants more of them than us. He's hoping it'll get us more comfortable being around Robinson. Higbe clears his throat, reads what he's written:

We, the undersigned Brooklyn Dodgers will not play ball on the same field as Jackie Robinson. Higbe signs it. He hands the pen to Bragan who adds his o name. Casey signs with a flourish. Casey holds out the pe to Walker who doesn't take it right away. An odd beat.
If you wanna make your mark, Dixie, we can witness it. Everyone laughs; it loosens Walker up enough to sign.
Higbe KNOCKS as Casey, Bragan and Walker crowd behind him
C'mon in!
The boys enter. Eddie Stanky sits in a chair stripped to waist, soaking his right elbow in a BUCKET OF ICE.
What's goin' on?
Got a petition goin' on, Stank.
To keep Robinson up in Montreal where he belongs.
Oh... Did Pee Wee sign it?
Ain't asked him yet. What difference does it make?
None, just wonderin'. BLUE REV 4-07-12 54. Stanky looks to Walker who looks away.
(re: his right arm) Can't sign now. I'm indisposed. Could I catch up with you later?
Standing in the door to his room. Looking out at the glum faces of Higbe, Bragan, Casey and Walker.
Look, it's like this. I got a wife, a baby, and I got no money. I don't want to step in anything.
Skip me, Dix, I'm not interested.
What if they put him at shortstop?
If he's man enough to take my job, I suppose he deserves it.
(laughs out loud) The hell he does!
He does not have the ice water in his veins for big league baseball.
So let him show what he's got. Robinson can play or he can't. It'll all take care of itself.
The very son of immigrants Rickey was talking about. From Pennsylvania no less.
Give me the pen. Higbe grins, hands it over. As Furillo signs...
Durocher lays staring up at the palm shadows on the ceili Finally, the phone rings. He answers.
Yes, Mr. Rickey.
Have our friends in the press gone to sleep yet?
We are the only people awake on  this entire isthmus, Mr. Rickey.
A deliberate violation of the law, needs a little show of force. I leave it to you. Good night, Leo.
Yes, Mr. Rickey.

Deserted. Durocher stands in a hotel bathrobe, arms cross as his PLAYERS and COACHES file in. Bleary-eyed, half- dressed, they're all here, all wondering what this is abo Suddenly, Durocher grabs the handle of an industrial-size SOUP POT and heaves it across the room. BRWANG-RANG-RANG!

Wake up, ladies! Wake the Hell up! (a stunned beat) It's come to my attention that some of you fellas don't want to play with Robinson. That you even got a petition drawn up that you're all gonna sign. Well boys, you know what you can do with your petition?

head_text.subj: YOU CAN WIPE YOUR ASSES WITH IT

text: C'mon, Leo...
Come on what?! TAN REV 6-25-12 55A.
Ball players gotta live together, shower together, it's not right to force him on us. Besides, I own a hardware store back home and I -- PINK REV 4-19-12 56.

Screw your hardware store, Dix! And if you don't like it, screw you! Mr. Rickey'll be happy to make other arrangements for you. Durocher suddenly marches to Higbe, looks like he's going belt him. As Higbe gulps, Durocher turns to the team.

I don't care if he's yellow or black or has stripes like a zebra, if Robinson can help us win, and everything I've seen says he can, then he's gonna play on this ball club. Like it, lump it, make your mind up to it because he's coming! And think about this when your heads hit the pillow, he's only the first, boys, only the first. More are coming right behind him. They have talent and they wanna play! He lets that sink a moment.

Yes, sir, they're gonna come diving and scratching. So I'd forget your petition and worry about the field. Because unless you fellas pay a little more attention to your work, they are going to run you right out of the ball park! A petition? (looks them over) Are you ballplayers or lawyers? As he marches past them and through the doors...
Jack in his Montreal uniform headed off the field for the dugout. Sukeforth headed over wearing Dodger blue.
Robinson!  As Jack turns, Sukeforth tosses him a FIRST BASEMAN'S GLO
What do you want me to do with this?
Play first base.
I've never played first base in my  life, Coach.
Well, it's like this. Brooklyn's  got a solid second baseman. And  they got Pee Wee Reese at short.  But first base is up for grabs. Are you catching my drift?
Yeah. I don't need a glove to do  that.

Coach Sukeforth, getting balls from a bucket, hitting grounders down to Jack at first. The short hops are wicke Jack rolls his catches over to a little PANAMANIAN KID wh chucks them down to his brother who tosses them back to  Sukeforth. As Jack struggles...
El es muy malo.
Mr. Rickey said he wants you playing conspicuous baseball!
To be so good the Dodgers'll demand you on the team!
So I thought about it awhile and then I looked up conspicuous in the dictionary.
It means to attract notice or attention. Jack dives, spears a liner. Sukeforth tilts back his cap.
Conspicuous.
Bobby Bragan sits across from Rickey looking defiant.
Bragan, most of your teammates have recanted on this petition nonsense. Are you really here to tell me you don't want to play with Robinson?
Yes, Sir. My friends back in Birmingham would never forgive me.

And your friends here in Brooklyn? (Bragan just shrugs) Then I will accommodate you. If you give me your word that you will try your very best for this team until I can work out a trade. That gets Bragan's goat. He jumps up, really mad.
Do you think I would quit on anyone?! I don't quit.
Only on yourself apparently. You can go, Bragan.

Time slowed way down as Jack takes a throw at second from Montreal shortstop. He pivots to turn the double-play eve as Dixie Walker barrels in low.  All Jackie's focus on the task at hand as he throws while Walker submarines him. He lands in a heap tangled up  together. They both look back to see the result of the pl As Robinson smiles and Walker scowls, we know...
Send Dixie in.
Sitting down across from Rickey.
I received your letter, Dixie.
Recently, the thought has occurred to me that a change of ball clubs would benefit both the Brooklyn Baseball Club and myself.
This is about Robinson?
I'm keeping my reasons private. Hope you can respect that, sir.

I realize, Dixie, that you have a Southern upbringing, that you would have to subordinate your feelings for the welfare of this venture. I for one would deeply appreciate it. I think we can all learn something.

What I have, Mr. Rickey, is a hardware store back home. It's called Dixie Walker's. Folks don't come because I have the lowest prices, they come because it's called Dixie Walker's. Understand? And I make as much money owning that store as I do playing for you.
Is that what you're you afraid of? (he doesn't answer) Bragan's a third-stringer, but you bat clean-up. You're popular in Brooklyn. Children look up to you!
You got my letter; can I go?
I'll start looking for a trade or a sale. But it won't happen until I get value in return. Until then I expect you to drive in runs.
I always have. That's my job.
INSERT: Manhattan. April 8, 1947. Jack exits with his luggage. Looking for a cab, he sees Smith waiting. Smith offers a salute. Jack looks grumpy a he steps over. The Buick waiting beyond.
You again. Smith leans back, blinks.
That's right. Me again. Something wrong with that, Jack?
Come on. Jack continues past. As Smith follows...
Traffic heavy. A glum silence in the car until...
They can't keep you on Montreal for long. After these exhibition games, they've got to bring you up.
You don't have two words to rub together, do you?
Do I have to entertain you? More silence, then...

You ever wonder why I sit out in right field with my typewriter on my knees? Does that ever cross your mind? Jack stares out the passenger window, not in the mood. As looks up at some of the taller buildings they pass...

It's because Negro reporters aren't allowed in the press box. Jack doesn't answer, doesn't look over. Finally Smith sta talking to himself. Pretending to be Jack.  GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 62. SMITH a AS JACK'  You know, Wendell, I never asked you where you were from?
Why I'm from Detroit, Jack. SMITH a AS JACK' You don't say? Tell me more.
My daddy used to work at Fair Lane. That was Mr. Ford's estate. My daddy was Mr. Henry Ford's cook. SMITH a AS JACK' I did not know that.

Cooked for him for years, but never once broke bread with him. I'd go to work with daddy sometimes. Play baseball out on the lawn with Mr. Ford's grandchildren. We all had a real good time. But it was understood, if they got tired of playing ball and moved inside to the bowling alley or swimming pool, I was not invited or allowed. The grass was as far as I got. So guess what? You're not the only one with something at stake here.
(after a beat) If I start talking, will you stop?
I'd be happy to. Smith stops at a red light.
I apologize. You've been there for me through this more than anyone besides Rae and Mr. Rickey. But I guess that's what bothers me.
How do you mean?
I don't like needing someone to be there for me. I don't like needing anyone but myself. I never have. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 63.
You are a hard case, Jack Robinson. Is it okay if I keep driving you or should I let you out so you can walk? Jack bursts out laughing. So does Smith.
You remember the last time we were  at a red light? Down in Florida?
New York City now, baby. We've  come a long way.
And we got a long way to go.  The light turns green. Off they go.
Rickey reads to Parrott from the New York Sun.
Branch Rickey cannot afford to upset team chemistry and so the only thing keeping Robinson off the Dodgers now, plainly, is the attitude of the players. INSERT: Brooklyn. April 9, 1947.

If it softens at the sight of Jackie's skills, he'll join the club some time between April 10 and April 15. Otherwise, Robinson will spend the year back in Montreal. (throws paper down) For the love of Pete, he batted .625 in the exhibition games against them, us, them -- Against us! Judas Priest! Rickey flummoxed as the phone RINGS from the outer office
Maybe you could have Durocher hold a press conference. Demand that he get Robinson on his team. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 63A.
Durocher. Of course, he's my ace in the hole. Very good, Harold. The phone still rings. Rickey looks to his open door.
Jane Ann! Are you out there? Grumbling, brambly eyebrows twitching, he makes the mista of answering his own phone. WHITE 3-14-12 64.
Branch Rickey... You're speaking to him... The Commissioner of what..? Oh, yes put him on. (looks to Parrott) The commissioner of baseball.
HAPPY CHANDLER gets a manicure. Always jovial, a head lik an anvil with hair parted in the middle, he picks up a ph
Branch, how are you?
Fine. What can I do for you, Happy?
Branch, how would you feel about losing Durocher for a year? Rickey switches the phone from one ear to the other.
I'm sorry, Happy, I thought you said lose Durocher for a year.
Yes. He was seen in Havana with known gamblers.
Anyone who sets foot in Havana is seen with known gamblers.
It's not just one thing, it's an accumulation. I received notice today from the Catholic Youth Organization. Vowing a ban on baseball unless Durocher is punished for his moral looseness.
You're joking.
It's this business with the actress in California. She's recently divorced and Durocher is the cause. They may even be illegally married. PINK REV 4-19-12 65.
Now I'm sure you're joking. Happy checks his nails, returns his hand to the MANICURIS
I wish I were. The CYO buy a lot of tickets, Branch. They draw a lot of water and I can't afford to ruffle their feathers. Am I mixing metaphors there?

You know very well my organization is about to enter a tempest. I need Durocher at the rudder. He's the only man who can handle this much trouble, who loves it in fact. You're chopping off my right hand!
I have no choice. I'm going to have to sit your manager, Branch. Leo Durocher is suspended from baseball for a year.
You can't do that! Happy, you son of a bitch! DIAL TONE. Rickey steadies himself, looks to Parrott.
Trouble ahead, Harold. Trouble.

Durocher, in a suit, cleans out his locker. Carefully set each item in a cardboard box. Finished, he closes the loc door. CLICK. And then -- WHAM! -- Drives his fist in, tak it off its hinges. He picks up his box, quietly walks out
RING... Jack asleep in bed, fumbles for the receiver.  INSERT: April 10, 1947.
Hello?
Mr. Robinson, this is Jane Ann in  Mr. Rickey's office. He needs to  see you right away. He has a  contract for you to sign.  That wakes him up.
Jack sits at the desk. Alone. He looks back over his  shoulder at the GOLDFISH. As one of them stares back, Ric enters with the CONTRACT in question. He sets it down bef Jack, hands him a pen.
I'm so sorry about the rush.  Events are unfolding too fast to  keep up with. The burden has  finally fallen to me and so be it.
Sign here?
Yes, yes.  As Jack poises the pen -- Rickey suddenly aghast.
Stop!  The pen a millimeter over the page.
History. And I'm blabbing,  blabbing through history... Rushing  it along. What am I thinking?  TAN REV 6-25-12 66A.
Rickey sticks his head out the door.
Jane Ann, come in here. (hollering down hall) Harold! Parrott sticks his head out from an office down the hall.
Get some employees up here!
Where Jack Robinson signs his contract. As he sets the pe down -- Rickey starts APPLAUDING. He's joined by Parrott, JANE ANN and a JANITOR. Rickey claps Jack on the shoulder

Harold, telegram the press. Say this: aThe Brooklyn Dodgers today purchased the contract of Jackie Robinson from the Montreal Royals. He will report immediately.a As Jack takes it in, he's the only one not smiling.
The phone rings. Rachel answers in her nightgown.
Hello?
Rae, I'm in Brooklyn. Brooklyn... Rachel lets out a triumphant WHOOP!
What did I tell you?
A few lights twinkle, but this city does occasionally sle TAN REV 6-25-12 67.

This man does not. He stands bare chested in his boxers staring out the window of a MCALPIN HOTEL ROOM. Consideri the world before him. Wondering where his place is in it. INSERT: April 15, 1947. 3 AM. It's a lonely moment. Until Rachel appears behind him in nightgown. She wraps her arms around him, looks over his shoulder at the world out there. Finally, softly...
I love you... As he closes his eyes, absorbs it...
Jack cruises down, stops in front of the PEPTO BISMOL. INSERT: April 15, 1947. 11 AM. As he grabs a bottle -- a man on the other side pulls one as well. Jack finds himself looking at Pee Wee Reese.
Jack and Reese exit together, each with a bottle of Pepto Bismol in hand. Reese hefts his bottle.
Opening day nerves. Doing my stomach something awful. Jack nods in commiseration. It's awkward between them. A RUMBLE as a GARBAGE TRUCK goes by.
There goes another one.
Every time I see a garbage truck go by I still can't figure why the guy driving isn't me.
We'd both better get on base. Reese nods. They start walking toward the stadium. TAN REV 6-25-12 68.
Know when I first heard of you?
No I don't.

On a troop transport, coming back from Guam. A sailor heard it on the radio, told me the Dodgers had signed a Negro player. I said that was fine by me. Then he said the guy was a shortstop. Least you were then. That got me thinking. Thinking gets me scared. Jack smiles, hefts his bottle of Pepto.
Black, white, we're both pink today, huh?
You still scared, Pee Wee?
(looks down street) Of garbage trucks? Terrified.
The Taj Mahal of baseball. Opening day.  INSERT: Ebbets Field. Brooklyn.

Some guys quiet, some guys joking around. Everyone in som version of getting out of their street clothes or into th uniforms. The entire operation comes to a halt as -- Jack enters. As he walks past -- some players nod hello. Others look like Sphinxes. Walker turns and faces his locker. Gene Hermanski and Branca step over to SHAKE HAND
I'm Hermanski. Welcome to Brooklyn.
Hey, man. Ralph Branca. Last, but not least, Spider Jorgensen, his Montreal teamm TAN REV 6-25-12 68A.
We made it, Jack, huh? Good luck. That's it. Everyone else is too busy to come over. As Jac scans for a locker with his name on it, BABE HAMBURGER, t clubhouse manager, steps over. WHITE 3-14-12 69.
You're looking for your locker, huh, kid? Follow me. They walk over to a hook on the wall. A uniform hangs fro it. A FOLDING CHAIR below.

I just got the word. Best I could do. I'll get you straightened out tomorrow though, huh? Jack nods, unbuttoning his shirt... Stanky is suddenly th All pugnacity as he gives up 4 inches and 40 pounds to Ja

You're putting on that uniform, it means you're on my team. But before I play with you I want you to know how I feel about it. I want you to know I don't like it. I want you to know I don't like you. Jack regards him. Stanky doesn't flinch. Maybe he should.
That's fine. That's how I prefer it. Right out in the open.
Standing before his steaming HOT DOG STAND.
C'mon, Brooklyn! Get your Harry M. Stevens special here! As he hands one over, gets his .20 cents in return. Then:
Hey, Lady! Rachel looks over, baby Jackie in her arms. The vendor ta a baby bottle out of the hot water in his STEAMER.
I think it's ready.

Looking at himself in a MIRROR. Standing in his uniform, clean white wool, the flowing script: Dodgers. It fits. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 70. We FOLLOW HIM past Stanky as he goes. Follow the BLUE 42 his back as he steps through the clubhouse.

head_text.subj: MAKES HIS WAY UP THE TUNNEL. 107

text: Always on that magic number as he comes up through the Do DUGOUT and steps onto...
PHOTOGRAPHERS snap photos, the crowd spot him and CHEER.
Watches from the stands. Pleased at the cheering. She hol the baby up to see, whispers to him...
Okay, okay, that's good. As Jackie's eyes find hers...

head_text.subj: THE PLAYERS LINED UP FOR THE NATIONAL ANTHEM 110

text: The Dodgers down one baseline, the BOSTON BRAVES down the other. Forty-nine white players and one black. Jack at th end alongside Ralph Branca. Jack trying not to choke up.
O'er the land of the free! And the home of the brave!
The players not starting return to the dugout. Bragan catches up with Branca.
You're crazy standing that close to him.
What do you mean?
What if the sharpshooter misses and hits you instead?
You got a serious problem, Bragan, you know that? WHITE 3-14-12 71.
Really? I don't see it.
Surveying the scene. Parrott alongside.
Opening day, Harold. The world is all future and no past.
A blank page, sir.
RED BARBER looks down onto the field.
One out in the bottom of the first. Headed toward the plate for his first big league at bat is Dodger rookie Jackie Robinson. Jackie is very definitely brunette.
Walks toward the plate. More cheers. Mostly.
We're with you, Jackie!
Hey, boy, how about a shine?! Jack struggles not to look back at the source of the jeer He settles in at the plate. JOHNNY SAIN on the mound wait for the sign. The crowd BUZZING.

Sain looking in. When he's got that fastball working, he can toss a lamb chop past a hungry wolf. The BRAVES CATCHER signals a 1'. Here come the pitch. CRA It's down the third base line. The THIRD BASEMAN is going to need every ounce of his arm he fields it at the line, throw across his body to -- FIRST. Where Jack's foot hits the bag an instant before t ball smacks into the first baseman's mitt. TAN REV 6-25-12 72.
You're out! Jack can't believe it. As he trots toward the dugout he looks at the umpire who looks back: I dare you to complai
As the Brooklyn faithful BOO the call, Rachel and Smith w Jack head decisively toward the dugout. He was safe. Rickey sits down closer to the dugout.
It's a game of inches, Jackie!
Get some glasses, ump!
BURT SHOTTON, 62, walks down the hallway with Parrott.  INSERT: April 18, 1947.
How's Florida, Burt?
Roses need pruning, but fine when I  left it last night. Branch said it  was important and I heard about  Leo. Any idea what this is about?
You'd better just talk to him.  A beat as they reach the door. Parrott knocks.
Come in!
Rickey smiles from his desk as they enter.  TAN REV 6-25-12 73.
Baseball has returned to Brooklyn, Burt. Another season is underway.
Yeah, it's a shame about Leo.
Inevitable I suppose. I asked him if she was worth it and he said yes. How's the retirement?
It's fine. The roses --
It's a helluva thing when a man has  good health and enough money and absolutely nothing to do.
I'm perfectly happy.
Is that so?
When I took off that Cleveland  uniform two years ago, I promised the Mrs. I'd never put on another uniform again. Roses look great  and I sleep a whole lot better.
Roses and sleep are two wonderful  things, Burt. But sleep you can  get inside your casket and flowers  look good on top of it. You don't  look like a dead man to me.
What's this about, Branch?  TAN REV 6-25-12 73A.
I need you to manage the Dodgers.  We're a ship without a captain; there's a typhoon ahead.
No, I'm sorry, but no.
Do you miss the game, Burt? Look  me in the eye and tell me you  don't.  Shotton considers Rickey a beat and then looks away.
Baseball's the only life for an old  pepper pot like me, but I promised  my wife, Branch.
You promised her you wouldn't put on another uniform. You didn't promise her you wouldn't manage.  Wear a suit and tie; Connie Mack  still does.
You remember how to get to the Polo  Grounds, Burt?
Branch, I --
You remember what the peanuts smell  like roasting, how the crack of the  bat sounds, the roar of the crowd?
Sure...  Rickey tosses him a set of car keys.
My car's parked right out front.  Harold will show you where. Now  what do you say?
Okay.
Shotton addresses the half-dressed Dodgers, Jack included

Men, I don't have much to say. Just, don't be afraid of old Burt Shotton as a manager. You can win the pennant in spite of me. I can not possibly hurt you. The Dodgers trade looks. Not exactly inspirational. As Shotton heads out he pauses by Jack.
Are you Robinson?
I thought so. Shotton pats Jack on the shoulder, continues on his way.
A huge CROWD beyond. Bob Cooke of the Herald Tribune (see at the Waldorf Astoria) holds court as Jack is ANNOUNCED.

Mark my words and circle this date. Negroes are going to run the white man straight out of baseball. I'm not prejudiced; it's physiological. They have a longer heel bone. Gives em an unfair speed advantage.
Standing dead still at the plate, bat cocked and ready.

Here's Robinson. Jackie holds that  club down by the end. Rear foot on  the back line of the box. Slight  open stance, bent at the knees...  Giants pitcher DAVE KOSLO goes into his wind-up and throw Jack swings. CRACK. The ball screams out to left. Home run! The crowd goes crazy. This is what they came to see.
Typewriters pounding away as Jack finishes his home run t Bob Cooke watching thoughtfully as... PINK REV 4-19-12 74A.
Was that because his heels are longer, Bob?! As everyone cracks up, everyone but Bob...

Jack and Rachel out for dinner. Jack nodding as BLACK PATRONS pass by, saying encouraging things. He almost get forkful of food to his mouth before a MENU and a PEN are offered for an autograph. As he signs, a FLASH BULB goes off. In a lull, Jack cuts his steak, low to Rachel.
I'm not complaining, I just, I don't know what they want.
They want to see if Jackie Robinson is real. They want to see your pride, your dignity. Because then they'll see it in themselves. He's stopped short. She blinks with mock coquettish modes
And me? I'm just young and scared and amazed at how brave you are. He grins at her, almost gets a forkful in when LAWSON BOW the Black owner, pulls up a chair, shakes Jack's hand.
I'm Lawson Bowman, Jack, the owner of this joint. How's the steak?
I'm not sure yet. It looks good.

BATHROOM MIRROR - Steamed. A finger traces a 42' in the s on the glass, then wipes it clean to reveal Rachel. Hair  wrapped in a towel, she looks at herself, frowns.  INSERT: Brooklyn, April 22, 1947.  DRYING DIAPERS - Hang like pennants on a line stretched  across the BEDROOM. Rachel ducks under them to retrieve h shoes. She looks at them, frowns.  RACHEL - Brushing her teeth. Pauses to hold the toothbrus in a batting stance. Swings...  RACHEL - Strains to reach to zip her dress up. She pulls the edges of the dress, straightens herself out. She look over at Jack Jr. who watches from his crib.  DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 75A.
You're lucky you're a boy. DOORWAY - Dressed to go, Rachel holding the baby, looking anxiously out on the street. Suddenly, ALICE the baby-sit is there. Here she comes up the steps, opens the door.
Sorry I'm late. Class ran long.
It's okay. Rachel gently hands the baby over.
It's so cold and raw out, I don't want him getting sick at the game.
He'll be nice and warm here.
