(checks her watch) I'm going to be late. She kisses him goodbye, frowns as she heads outside --
A forboding sky above as Rachel hurries along. Pulling he jacket on as she goes. It's going to be a cold day.
The sky's are leaden. Threatening.  Eddie Stanky safe at first as  Robinson steps to the plate.
Brooklyn vs. Philadelphia. The bottom of the first. The crowd CHEERS. Stanky safe on first.
The sky's are leaden. Threatening. Eddie Stanky safe at first as Robinson steps to the plate. Jack walk to the plate, digs a cleat into the batter's bo
Hey! Hey you black Nigger! Jack looks to the visitor's dugout where the Phillies Ala born manager BEN CHAPMAN stands at the top of the steps. DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 75AA.
Why don't you go back to the cotton fields where you belong! GREEN REV 4-27-12 76. The bear baiting has begun. Jack is in a kind of temporar shock. That's the Phillies manager! In uniform.
Or did you swing your way out of the jungle?! Bring me a banana!
Chapman the Phillies manager up on the top step, seems to be chirping something out to Robinson. Chapman a hothead during his playing days with the Yankees.
Sitting next to Parrott. He leans forward, unsure.
What's he saying?
Chapman joined by two of his PHILLIE BENCH PLAYERS.

Go home, Nigger! Go back to Africa! Phillie pitcher DUTCH LEONARD looks in. Jack has to try t concentrate on the pitch. Here it comes. A fastball well inside. Jack hits the deck to keep from getting beaned.
Bojangles! You sure can dance, snowflake!
On first, mouth hanging open. Almost forgets to take a le It's an instant Rorschach test.
Shotton and the players look stricken. Even Walker doesn' quite know what to make of it. No one enjoys it, but Higb
CONCESSION MEN walk closer to listen. The fans range from horrified to some mildly pleased. Rachel looks stricken. PINK REV 4-19-12 76A.
A fastball inside. He leaps back again. This one was even closer to hitting him. As Jack glares at Dutch...
Ball two!

Hey, black boy! Hey, shoe shine! WHITE 3-14-12 77. Jack doesn't want to look over, but he is compelled. The bench players flanking Chapman look furious, but Chapman doing this with a sick sort of glee.
You like white girls?! Huh?! Which one of them Dodger boys' wives are you climbing on tonight?! Chapman looks toward...
They don't like that one.
Oh, I think I got it. Dixie, I believe I know!

Grips the bat. Watches for the next pitch with bloody mindedness. He hacks at it, lofts a routine fly into left He's about halfway down to first when the left fielder catches it and Jack can mercifully return to the dugout.
Rickey watches as he disappears inside. Finally exhales.

Jack sits down. No one says anything to him. No one comes near him as he stares ahead, trapped in a kind of void. T closest player to him is Bobby Bragan. Bragan finally manages to glance over at him, then looks quickly away.
As the Dodgers take the field, Jack heads to first. Almos wincing, wondering if it's going to start again.
(under her breath) Look at me, baby. Look at me. Finally, Jack glances up to her. She offers her eyes: I'm with you. He looks away. Her witnessing makes it worse.
Settles back in the shadows of the dugout. Finished for n
No score. Bottom of the 3rd.
Spider Jorgensen takes a lead off first. At the plate, Stanky lines a single to right. Jorgensen holds at second
Steps to the batter's box, starts digging in that back fo
As Chapman emerges with his two bench players.
Hey, Nigger lips! Party's over, jungle bunny!
Hey, Pee Wee! Dixie! What's this Nigger doing for you all to let him drink from the same water fountain as you?! I hope it's worth it!
Waiting for the pitch. Takes a mighty swing -- CRACKS a towering POP-UP between home plate and the mound. Dutch watches his catcher Seminick settle under it. Waiting.
Hey, is that a home run!?
Yeah! If you're playing in an elevator shaft! Jack veers off the first baseline. Heads for the dugout.
You don't belong! Look in a mirror! This is a white man's game. Get it through your thick monkey skull! Jack stops short looks at him. Chapman stands his ground.
Stands, watches. Praying this doesn't go south. As Jack finally continues on, Rickey closes his eyes in relief.
Sick for her husband. WHITE 3-14-12 79.
Jack stalks down past the team. No one looks at him. Brag is ashamed. Dixie tries to look disinterested. Stanky and Reese exchange a helpless glance as Jack continues into:

Like a bull on his way to slaughter, he revolts. WHAM-WHA He proceeds to turn his bat into SPLINTERS. Concrete chip wood flies. Jack drops the handle of the bat, pounds his fists. Heaving for breath, framed by the empty tunnel. Ra electric, ungovernable. All the anger on display, the fur FEET SCRAPE. Jack looks up to see Rickey standing there, watching, afraid to get too much closer.
To hell with this. The next white son of a bitch who opens his mouth, I'll smash his goddamn teeth in. Rickey stands there until finally, opening his mouth...
You can't, Jackie. You know it.
I'm supposed to let this go on?
These men have to live with
I have to live with myself, too! And right now I'm living a sermon out there. I'm through with it! Jack is at the end of his rope. All Rickey has are words.
You don't matter right now, Jack. You're in this thing. You don't have the right to pull out from the backing of people who believe in you, respect you and who need you.
Is that so?
If you fight, they won't say Chapman forced you to; they'll just say that you're over your head. That you belong where you are.
That every downtrodden man who wants more from life is over his head. Jack's either going to explode or break into tears.
Do you know what it's like, having someone do this to you?!
No. You do. You're the one living the sermon. In the wilderness. Forty days. All of it. Only you.
And not a damn thing I can do about it.

Of course there is! You can stand up and hit! You can get on base and you can score! You can win this game for us! We need you as well! Everyone needs you. (a beat; exhausted) You're medicine, Jack. Rickey reaches out, touches the wall to stay standing. Ja just breathes as familiar sounds reverb down the tunnel.
They're taking the field.
Who's playing first? Jack considers him. Everything hangs in the balance. Then
I'm gonna need a new bat. As Jack heads back down the tunnel for the field.
Eight zeros hang for the Phillies. Seven for the Dodgers. No score, the bottom of the 8th coming up.
Steps into the batter's box. Chapman and his sidekicks st from the Stygian abyss of the visitor's dugout. PINK REV 4-19-12 81.

Hey, black Nigger! I know you can hear me! If you were a white boy, you know where you'd be right now?! On a bus headed down to Newport News cuz you can't play for shit! Here comes the pitch. Jack nonchalantly sticks his bat ou pokes a soft hit past second. A nothing hit, but he's standing on first. And he looks, well, ferocious in fact. As Pete Reiser steps up into the batter's box... Jack stares at Dutch Leonard. Assassin's eyes as he takes insolent, in-your-face lead off first. Dutch fires to first. Jack dives back safe! Back on his feet, he spits out a piece of grit he picked sliding back on his belly. Not bothering to dust himself off, he's turning into something elemental before our eye
Up in the booth.
Two strikes now to Reiser as Leonard looks in. Robinson with another big lead off first. He's as  restless as a cat with a hot foot.
Witnessing.
Steal it, sweetheart. Take it.

Dutch throws. Jack on the run as Reiser swings and misses STRIKE THREE! - and Seminick comes up throwing. Jack slides into second, the throw high, ends up in cente Half a dozen Dodgers impulsively on their feet and waving on as Jack gets to his feet and motors into THIRD. The th well late. Phillies third baseman HANDLEY throws the ball back to Dutch. Handley then looks to Jack.
I'm sorry. I want you to know what goes on here, it don't go for me. Jack barely nods, but he heard. BLUE REV 4-07-12 82.
Hermanski steps up.

Dutch looking to third, nodding distracted at a sign, loo back to third before... Hermanski cracks a single to left As Jack crosses the plate, he stares down Chapman on his to the dugout. As Chapman turns his head, spits --
Several REPORTERS around Chapman as well. He drinks a BEE
You fellas are making too big a deal out of this. He scored We lost. One to nothing.
Do you think you were a little hard on Robinson?

We treat him the same way we do Hank Greenburg except we call Hank a kike instead of a coon. When we play exhibitions against the Yankees, we call DiMaggio the Wop. They laugh at it. No harm, it's forgotten after the game ends. Chapman tosses away his beer can.
Don't you think this was maybe one foot over the line?
Hey. Let's get the chips off our shoulders and play ball. It's a game, right?

Jack alone in the shower. Water beating down. Steam risin A warrior who survived another day of battle. Maybe. They say the Lord doesn't ask us to bear any more than we're a but God is cutting it pretty damn close here. He is in pa
Rickey sits brooding, thinking. Parrott enters, upset.
I'm going in that Phillie dugout tomorrow and wring Chapman's neck! Rickey considers Parrott, starts laughing. Parrott is hur
Did I say something funny?
When I first told you about Jackie, you were against it. Now all of a sudden you're worrying about him. How do you suppose that happened?
Well, any decent minded person --
Sympathy, Harold, is a Greek word. It means to suffer. I sympathize with you means I suffer with you. This Philadelphia manager has done me a service.
A service?!
Is there an echo in here? Yes, he's creating sympathy on Jackie's behalf. Philadelphia by the way is Greek for brotherly love. The intercom BUZZES.
Bob Bragan to see you, Mr. Rickey.
What in Satan's fire does he want?
Send him in. Rickey pretends to review papers as Bragan enters, his ha literally in his hand. Rickey lets him stand there a mome
What do you want, Bragan? WHITE 3-14-12 84.
I'd like not to be traded, sir, if it isn't too late.
What about Robinson? Bragan's been staring at the floor. He looks up now. The low afternoon sun hits his face.
I'd like to be his teammate.
Why?
The world's changing; I guess I can live with the change.
Red Sox just offered Ted Williams, but I'll see what I can do.
Thank you, Mr. Rickey. Bragan leaves. Rickey looks at Parrott: a What do you kno
Rachel waiting. Jack exits, sees her, hadn't expected her
You shouldn't have waited.
They haven't made a day long enough that I wouldn't wait for you.
Give these boys time. It's a three game series. A beat between them, framed by the steel girders around t

I don't care if they like me; I didn't come here to make friends. I don't even care if they respect me. I know who I am; I got enough respect for myself. But I do not want them to beat me. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 85.
They are never going to beat you.
They're taking their best shot. I don't want you coming tomorrow. I don't want you to watch that, them beating me.
Wherever you are, I am, too. Look at me. Jack... He looks over. It's not easy for this most proud of men.
I have to watch. So our hearts don't break... Plus I already bought a scorecard. She holds it up. His name the only one filled in.
And I put your name on it. See? Jack Robinson. He puts his hand out, takes hers.
I did good the day I met you.
Baby, you hit a home run.
The SCOREBOARD shows 1 run scored by the Phillies in the of the first. Jack steps up to the plate. Here we go agai INSERT: April 23, 1947. The next day.
Hey, porch monkey! Hey Robinson! Hey boy! You know why you're here?
On the bench. Without warning, he blasts off it. MOVE WIT him as he marches toward Chapman who doesn't see him comi
You're here to draw those Nigger dollars at the gate for Rickey! YELLOW REV 4-24-12 86. Chapman clocks the apoplectic Stanky. Spit flying as:
Sit down. Sit down or I'll sit you down.
What's the problem, Stank?
You're the problem, you goddamn disgrace! What kind of man are you?! You know he can't fight! Pick on someone who can fight!

Eddie Stanky having a chin wag with  his ex-teammate Chapman. Both men  masters of distraction. Eddie, of  course, from second. Chapman from  the dugout.  Stanky so mad he can't see straight. Chapman surrenders.
Okay, okay. Jesus. As Chapman disappears into his dugout, Jack whacks a sing
Stanky sits here stewing. His head down.

Robinson on first, Pete Reiser at  bat. Reiser belts it. A long one.  Deep into left center. Back goes  Ennis who is not tall enough. This  one's off the wall. Robinson is  going to score from first.  Over Barber: a CRACK of the bat, the ROAR of the crowd. A players around him react, Stanky finally looks up as Robi crosses the plate, heads in, sits a few feet from Stanky.
Thanks.
For what? You're on my team. What the hell am I supposed to do?
I gotta look in the mirror, too. PINK REV 4-19-12 86A. Stanky stands, walks away. Today's gonna be okay.
A BLACK PREACHER leads his congregation in prayer.

Lord, make me an instrument of your peace. Where there is hatred, let me sow love. Where there is injury, let me sow pardon. Where there is darkness, let me sow light. a Amens'. We see Rickey sits in the back row, the day hea on him. A YOUNG GIRL turns, looks at him. Why's a white m here? Rickey smiles, puts a finger to his lips... Shhhh.
Players put on their uniforms as Higbe, in street clothes fires the contents of his locker into a cardboard box. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 87B.
I speak my mind and they trade me! This ain't the America I know! He glares down to Jack's locker. Jack regards him back. It's Higbe who looks away first. He continues packing.
Where are they sending you, Hig?
Pittsburgh! For cash and some I- talian outfielder named Gionfriddo!
Pittsburgh...
Dixie Walker takes batting practice, drives the ball all the field. A natural. Rickey and Shotton watch from behind the backstop.
Do you remember the story, Burt, of the 99 sheep? How one was missing?
If you're talking about Dixie, I'd leave the word sheep out of it.
I find myself at odds. I want integration and the pennant. I want to punish Dixie and at the same time I want his salvation.
Can't he just be a good ballplayer? He has to be a good person, too?
It would be so much simpler if he wasn't batting .385.  As Walker finishes, he passes Jack whose turn it is.
She's all yours, Robinson.  As THUNDER rumbles in the distance...
Rain beats on the windows. Rickey looks over as Parrott  rushes in; he's out of breath and dripping wet. Parrott  holds up the Herald Tribune sports section.
The news isn't good, sir.
Nevertheless it must be accepted  calmly, Harold. What is it?  A headline: PLAYERS STRIKE. Parrott reads...

A National League players' strike  instigated by some of the St. Louis Cardinals against the presence of Negro first baseman Jackie Robinson has been averted temporarily and perhaps permanently quashed.
Madness! What are they thinking?!
Wendell Smith waits under an umbrella as the CARDINALS ge off the team bus. Smith buttonholes manager EDDIE DYER.
Eddie, what's all this talk about your Cardinals refusing to play?
We're here, aren't we? We didn't come to New York to go to Macy's. Dyer continues past him. Here comes big JOE GARAGIOLA.
Hey, Garagiola --
Get lost. Here comes STAN MUSIAL, a class act if there ever was one
Hey, Stan, what's the story?  TAN REV 6-25-12 88A.
This is big league baseball, not  English tea. Couple a guys  might've popped off; it's hot air.
Smith types out his report. As rain lashes the window, th Empire State building looms a few block away.
St. Louis didn't win the world championship last year without using their heads. They have the same heads this year and should know that they can't pick the players of another club.
Jack sits here alone, tending to a bat. Cleaning it with rubbing alcohol, handling it like the friend it is. Ricke joins him. He has a newspaper in hand. He holds it up.
National League President Frick says this is America and baseball is America's game. He says one citizen has as much right to play as another.
Baseball will go on as planned once  the rain stops.  Jack eyes his bat.
Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?

Because my job is to win. I have an obligation to Brooklyn to put the best team on the field I can. Your presence on the roster increases our chances of winning. Not buying it, Jack looks over at him.
If this is winning, I'd hate to see us on a losing streak.
Guys change into their street clothes. Branca reads to Re from the New York Post. Walker listens in from his locker
Listen to this: Right now Robinson  is the loneliest man I have ever  seen in sports.

Who's this guy to say Jackie's  lonely? He doesn't wear it on his  sleeve. Man's got one helluva game  face. Take no prisoners. How does  some reporter know how he feels.  They stop talking as Robinson walks past, the last one in the shower, a couple of towels around him.  GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 89A.
Lonely? I say its the best game  face in the world.
So long as he showers lonely, he  can have whatever face he wants.

location: EBBETS FIELD STANDS, (BETWEEN FIRST AND HOME)

text: Rachel sitting here. This section about two-thirds full.  INSERT: May 6, 1947. Brooklyn. Then, about five rows behind her, two RACIST FANS find th seats. They spot Jack down at first.
Look there he is! Black as the ace of spades! GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 90.
Damn! You believe that? A genuine nigger in a Dodger uniform. As Rachel winces at his words --
Shut up and go back to St. Louis!
Hey, you got a nigger on your team!
So what?! He's better than anyone you got!
Wait'll his cousin wants your job! Don't you know nothing?
Don't you?!
He's a nigger! Hey, black boy! Rachel stares ahead, tries to maintain. She shows them he back, sits up as straight as she can. Her movements heroi
Jack steps up against the Cardinals. Garagiola, the catch shouts down to third.
Watch this guy! He can't hit! Especially the curve! He can only get on base bunting! As Jack digs into the box.

Take your time, Robinson, you're digging your own grave. Big RED MUNGER looks in for the sign. Garagiola flashes a sign: a 1'. Wants it inside. Here's the pitch. Inside. Jack just scoots back. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 90A.
Takes a fastball in on the hands. Robinson, who is pitched to a great deal that way, uses a thicker handle bat than most hitters, just because he hits a lot of balls out on his hands.
Jack edges up closer to the plate.
What's your average, Joe?
It'd be a lot higher than yours, if I could run as fast as you can.
No matter how fast you run, you'll never hit as much as you weigh. Garagiola signals for another fastball.
C'mon, Munger! Boy's got a hole in his bat! Munger throws inside. Jack falls back, strokes a double into the gap.
That one wasn't quite a in' enough. Robinson punishing the Redbirds with a smart piece of hitting.

location: EBBETS FIELD STANDS, (BETWEEN FIRST AND HOME)

text: The Brooklyn fans cheer; the Racist fan sulks. The double little comfort to Rachel who stares ahead, sitting as straight up as she can. Willing herself not to cry.
Jack and Rachel ride home. Forlorn, she stares out.
Oh Jack...
What is it, Rae?
Nothing. It's just, sometimes when I sit up there with those bastards,  those loudmouths in the stands, I  know you can hear them.
Don't worry. It's okay.
No, it's not okay. And I can hear  them, too.  Jack looks at her, takes her hand in his.
I know. I'm sorry for that.  Rachel squeezes his hand back.
We're in it together. When they  start in on you, you know what I do? I try to sit up as straight.
Yeah?
Straight as I can.
I got it in my head that I can block it from you, some of it, if I sit up straight. (a sad smile) Isn't that dumb? Closing the space between them, he takes her hand.
It worked. I didn't hear a thing. She tries to smiles. As the tears streak her cheeks, he leans in kisses her forehead.
They're just ignorant.
If they knew you, they'd be ashamed. She puts her arm around him, draws that strength.
Hold on.
I am holding on.
Long as we hold on, it'll be okay.
WHACK! Rachel and Rickey watch Jack taking batting practi
You look lovely, Mrs. Robinson.
Thank you.

I don't know how you do it. Every day, from the 1st to the 9th. Myself? I could pay $100 for a suit and in twenty minutes I'd look like I fell out of bed. Even my shoes look rumpled. They watch Jack crack one high off the Schaefer Beer sign
I used to think Jack was conceited.  GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 93.
Is that so?
It was the very first thing I noticed about him.
How did you two meet?
I saw him at a UCLA football game. Even in uniform with a helmet on, his vanity was awful. It was the  way he held his hands on his hips. I hated him!

And on campus he always wore crisp white shirts and I'd think his skin is so dark, why would he do that? Then I got to know him, his pride and confidence, and I realized he was showing off his color. I was wrong. He wasn't conceited; he was  proud. Always, of who and what he  is. I'd never met another man like that. What about you? How did you meet your wife?
Trying to catch her in a race. She was the fastest girl in town. Beautiful legs. I finally caught up; we've been together ever since. They sit a moment. Below: Jack nails another one.
I wanted to apologize to you.
For what?
Everything. I can't apologize to him. He and I both knew what we were getting into. But you. A newlywed, trying to blossom a marriage under all this pressure.
Don't worry about me. Or us. We know who we are. Crack. Jack hits another. WHITE 3-14-12 94.
Your husband has humbled me. When this all began I thought I was changing the world and that Jackie was my instrument. Can you imagine? I wish I could help him, but I'm just a spectator.
You help him plenty. Believe me. They watch him rip into another pitch.
Is he able to get things off his chest? So he doesn't burn up?
Yes. I have to let him have that silence at first, let him come to me. But he opens up eventually.

Good. It's too much to carry inside. Does he have any friends on the team? (she gives him a look) They're spectators, too. They do admire him though. Rachel looks out to where Reese and Stanky play catch.
Do you think so?
Even the worst of us recognizes courage. Moral courage especially. I have to think they see it. Jackie's a man on trial. He's responding with glory and grace. No one can take their eyes off him.
He's had himself on trial since the day I met him. No man is harder on himself or gets to himself worse than Jack. But I hope his team- mates know, they're on trial too.
I suppose we all are. You're an astute woman, Mrs. Robinson. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 95.
I have to be, Mr. Rickey, I'm married to a man of destiny. I can't let him down.
If I'd met you first, I wouldn't  have looked so long for Jackie.
How do you mean?
I mean if he was good enough for  you, he's certainly good enough for  the rest of us.
Phillie GM HERB PENNOCK at his desk, on the phone.
Branch, it's Herb.
What can I do for you, Herb?
How long have we known each other?
Twenty years. Maybe more.
Then trust me when I say, Brooklyn's due here tomorrow, but you can not bring that Nigger down here with the rest of your team. Rickey grits his teeth, stays civil.
And why's that, Herb? His name's Jackie Robinson by the way.
We're just not ready for this sort of thing in Philadelphia.
GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 95aA.
I'm not sure we'll be able to take the field against your team if that boy is in uniform.

Herbert, what your team does is your decision. But my team is coming to Philadelphia. With Robinson. If we have to claim the game as a forfeit, we will. That's 9-0 in case you forgot. PINK REV 4-19-12 95A.
Branch, you've got one helluva hair  across your ass on this thing and  I, for one, would like to know what  you're trying to prove?
Do you think God likes baseball? I  do.
What the hell does that mean?

It means you're going to meet God  one day, Herb, and when he inquires  why Robinson wasn't on the field in  Philadelphia and you answer because  he was a Negro, it may not be a  sufficient reply.  As Rickey hangs up the phone...
The Dodger TEAM BUS pulls up. The doors whoosh open; Parr steps off looking official. As the players start to follo INSERT: May 9, 1947. Benjamin Franklin Hotel, Philadelphi

Come on, fellas! We have twenty  minutes to check in and then get to  Shibe! Chop chop.  No one is listening as the TEAM DRIVER opens the lower  compartment and the players (including Jack) grab their b
Out! Get that bus out of here!  The HOTEL MANAGER stalks over, flanked by HOTEL SECURITY.
We're the Dodgers. We have a  reservation.
Your team's not welcome, not while  you have ballclub Negroes with you.
You mean Robinson can't stay here?
I mean the entire team is refused!
We've been staying here ten years.
And you can stay away that long!
(last off the bus)  Hold on now, let's talk about this.  The Hotel Manager jerks his thumb like an umpire.
Get out! Now, grandpa!

Grandpa? Hey hold on, you!  Security getting between as Shotten and the Manager go at BLUE REV 4-07-12 96A. Jack is embarrassed, but what can he do? Walker says to n one in particular, but loud enough for Jack to hear:
Maybe 42's got enough friends in town, we can bunk up.
What's that supposed to mean?
Nothing. It's just, I know when  you can't get into a hotel, you got people's houses you can stay at.
What do you want from me, Walker?
An apology.
For what? Places like this?  Parrott alarmed at this turn of events.
For turning this season into a  sideshow! I'm a ballplayer; I want  to play ball!
So am I! I'm here to win!
How the hell are we gonna win  sleeping on the bus?!
It might do you some good the way  you're swinging the bat lately.
Watch your mouth!  PINK REV 4-19-12 97. Walker jabs his chest with a finger; Jack bats his hand a
Watch your damn hand! And they're lunging at each other. Separated by Reese, Stanky, Branca and Bragan while other players hold off Shotton. Two fights about to break out at the same time.
Grandpa?! I'll show you grandpa! Parrott summons something deep, lets loose a shrill WHIST
Fellas! Burt! Please! Take the bus to the field! Worry about the game. I'll find another hotel.
Ben Chapman sits across from Herb Pennock who flips throu underlined newspaper reports. Pennock reads one:

There is a great lynch mob among us; they go unhooded and work without rope. (looks at him) That's you, not me. (reads some more) We must remember that all this country's enemies are not beyond the frontiers of our home land.
Some Jew must've wrote that.
This doesn't look good, Ben! It makes the Phillies, look racist! You've got to do something.
Me?!
ON PARROTT. He's trying to work up the nerve for somethin Finally, he comes around the corner where Jack sits at hi locker talking to Smith.
Jackie, excuse me, um, a request  came in. The Phillies manager Ben Chapman, he'd like his photo taken  with you. Jack pretends to sniff the air around Parrott.
You been drinking, Harold?
Mr. Rickey thinks it's a good idea. He says it'll be in every sports page in the country. An example that'll show everyone even the most hardened man can change.
Chapman hasn't changed. He's just trying to take the heat off.
Mr. Rickey says it doesn't matter if he's changed. As long as it looks like he's changed. Chapman  said he'd come down here. Or meet  you in the runway.  As Jack slow burns...
See the ball come in slow. See the  photo come in slower.
Tell him on the field. Where  everyone can see him. As Parrott smiles; he's done it.
Perfect.
Chapman and Jack stand side-by-side facing the PRESS. Chapman makes a little speech. Hypocrisy at its best.

Jackie's been accepted in baseball and the Philadelphia organization wish him all the luck we can. I only hope in some small way our trial of fire... helped him along. Jack looks at him: Did he just say that? GREEN REV 4-27-12 99.
How about a picture? Shake hands. Bury the hatchet?
You want a picture? Sure. Jack steps to the on-deck circle, grabs a BASEBALL BAT. Chapman's eyes widen as he starts toward him with it.

(low to Chapman) We'll hold the bat. That way we don't have to touch skin. Chapman nods, looks relieved. A photographer hands over a bat. Chapman has two hands on the handle. Jack puts one hand on the barrel, the other stays on his hip.
Ben, I hope all your friends back home like the picture. Jack smiles as the flashbulbs go off. Chapman looks dumb.
By the dugout with Stanky, watches in disbelief.
Carl, I swear, I never thought I'd see ol' Ben eat shit like that.

FRITZ OSTERMUELLER on the mound. He takes a long look in Jack, at his catcher KLUTTZ who flicks his thumb: a Hit h INSERT: May 17, 1947. Pittsburgh. Here it comes. All Jack has time to do is cover his face lessen the blow. Beaned in the head, he goes down in a he Branca leads the Dodger players out onto the field. The UMPIRES move to head them off. Pirates as well. Kirby Higbe, now in a Pirate uniform, claps his hands pleased.
(in his face) Ostermeuller, you kraut! You gotta bat, too! Don't you forget!
I'm ready, you Wop bastard! PINK REV 4-19-12 99A.
It's gonna come right between your  eyes! Like a Kamikaze!
For him!? He doesn't belong here!
You don't belong here! Go home to  Goering and Shmelling!
Make me, you goddamn dago!  WHITE 3-14-12 100. As an UMPIRE gets between them, Jack sits up. He's okay.
Rickey looks up as Reese enters. He holds a LETTER.
What can I do for you, Pee Wee?
Well, Mr. Rickey, it's like this, the series in Cincinnati next week.
It's an important road trip, we're only three games out of first.
Yes, sir. You know, I'm from Kentucky.
Cincinnati's nearly a home game for you.
I got this letter, sir. I guess some people aren't too happy about me playing with Robinson. Rickey is not liking where this is going; he motions for letter, scans it, reads the highlights...
Nigger lover. Watch yourself. We will get you, carpetbagger. (holds it out) Typical stuff. Reese takes the letter back, a little hurt.
It's not typical to me.
How many of these letters have you gotten, Pee Wee?

Just this. Ain't that enough? Rickey looks Reese over a moment. Pushing back his chair steps over to a filing cabinet. WHITE 3-14-12 101. Motioning Reese to join him, he pulls open a drawer, pull out a 4-inch stack of flattened letters, then another, th third. He looks to Reese.
What are those?
I'll tell you what they aren't, they aren't letters from the Jackie Robinson fan club. Here -- He thrusts a sheaf of it into Reese's hands. As Reese fli through the stack of hate, reads:
Get out of baseball, or your baby boy will die.
Quit baseball or your Nigger wife will be... Reese trails off, won't say it out loud. Skips to another
Get out of the game or be killed. He looks at one more, reacts to the vitriol, but does not utter it. Reese looks back at Rickey, shocked.
Does Jackie know?
Of course he knows. And the FBI. They're taking a threat in Cincinnati pretty seriously. So excuse me if I'm not too shocked at you being called a carpetbagger. You should be proud of it!
We'd just like to play ball, Mr. Rickey. That's all we want to do.

I understand. I bet Jackie just wants to play ball. I bet he wishes he wasn't leading the league in hit by pitch. I bet he wishes people didn't want to kill him. But the world isn't so simple anymore. I'm not sure it ever was. We just, baseball ignored it. Now we can't. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 102.
Yes, Sir. I gotta get to practice.
In the stands. Freckled, cute. Looking at the men around him, his own FATHER SHOUTING at Jack as the Dodgers take field (the Reds coming off it).  Jack headed for first. Pee Wee out to short.
Nigger! (then...) We don't want you here! INSERT: Crosley Field, Cincinnati, June 21, 1947.

Cincinnati fans expressing their displeasure as the Dodgers take the field. Jackie Robinson at first. The Brat Eddie Stanky at second. Spider Jorgensen at third. And the captain Pee Wee Reese at shortstop.
Ask any man and they'll tell you that the Gillette Superspeed razor is a honey. Maybe the sweetest shaving razor you'll ever use.

Jack reaches first, throws the ball around the infield. M in the crowd beyond rise to jeer and heap abuse. COON! SHINE! Jack tries to let it wash over him. At short, Reese receives the ball, moves to throw to firs when he pauses. Deciding, he suddenly moves to trot acros the diamond until he's alongside Jack.
What's up? Now cries of CARPETBAGGER! cut through. PEE WEE, HOW CAN PLAY WITH THIS BLACK BASTARD!? Reese stares up at the wor hecklers along the first base line. He looks a little sad
They can say what they want; we're here to play baseball.
Just a bunch of crackpots still fighting the Civil War.
Hell, we'd a won that son of a gun if the cornstalks had held out. We just ran out of ammunition. Jack laughs. Reese has a funny way of saying it.
Better luck next time, Pee Wee. Reese impulsively puts his arm around Jack's shoulder, st into the Cincy dugout.
Ain't gonna be a next time. All we got is right now. This right here. Know what I mean? Walker reacting out in right. The crowd shuts down, some shock at the gesture. Jack surprised also.
Thank you, Jackie.
What're you thanking me for?
I've got family here from Louisville. Up there somewhere. I need a em to know who I am. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 104. Jack moved by Pee Wee's gesture, can't find the words.
Robinson and Reese conferring at  first. Maybe discussing an infield  shift on Baumholtz.
Hey! Number one! You playing ball or socializing?
Playing ball, ump! Playing ball!
Maybe tomorrow we'll all wear 42. That way they won't be able to tell us apart. Reese heads for short. Jack pounds his fist in his glove.
Jack playing Gin Rummy with Branca, Reese and Wendell Smi
(to Smith; teasing) You ever write about white guys in your paper? I mean, if I threw a no hitter and Jackie got a base hit, what would the headline be?
Jackie leads Dodgers to victory. Again. Under that: white Italian guy does ok. They all laugh.
I'd call your folks for ya, Ralph. Tell a em how you did.
No problem. It'll still make the Post. They play their hands as they talk. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 105.
We are on some kind of winning streak, huh boys? And I don't mean cards.
Hey, maybe forty of our last fifty.
Thirty-two and fifteen actually. Since the 4th of July.
Math is why I throw a baseball for a living.
This next series against the Cardinals, it's a big one. They look over at Jack who hasn't said a word. It's his play. He lays his cards down. Deadpan as he wins the hand
Gin.
The top of the 11th inning, all  tied at 2. For those of you just  tuning in, how did we get here?
Jack strokes a DOUBLE over Stanky's head as Stanky breaks second for third.
It's been double trouble as  Robinson knocked in Stanky with a  double in the third...

head_text.subj: B172 DIXIE WALKER AT BAT B172

text: Walker strokes a DOUBLE over Stanky's head as Stanky brea off second for third.
...And Dixie Walker did the same  with a double in the eighth.  GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 105A.
ENOS SLAUGHTER steps in for St. Louis. Hugh Casey on the mound for Brooklyn. Slaughter looks fiercely determined.

It wasn't enough as the Cardinals tied it with two of their own in the top of the ninth. This game is crucial to the Red Birds. They're five games out, the Dodgers having not relinquished first place sine June 30th. Casey throws a pitch. Inside, a ball. INSERT: August 20, 1947. Brooklyn.

Slaughter takes ball one low. Casey in his second inning of relief. This game is tighter than a new pair of shoes on a rainy day. Slaughter hitless in four trips as  Casey goes into his wind-up.  Slaughter swings, hits a hard ground ball right at Reese fires over to Jack at first. Slaughter is out by fifteen feet, but he never slows down. And his foot comes down -- -- High on Jack's right calf. Slaughter's spiked him something wicked. Jack goes down in a heap clutching his leg, blood already seeping through his high socks. Slaughter, head down, on his way to the visitor's dugout Dodger players pour out of their own to protest. As the U raises his hands, motions them all back... Jack pulls up sock, a bloody mess. Stanky looks to Casey. WHITE 3-14-12 106.
Next batter, throw right at his head. Clean his clock --

Just get him out. Understand? Game's too important. As Casey nods, Jack reaches up to Stanky and Reese. They pull him to his feet. Jack looks, finds Rachel in th stands. As he gives her a little wave: a I'm okay.'
A big Cardinal slugger at bat. Casey pitching.
The top of the 12th and Kurowski at the plate. He hit his 20th home run on Monday so Casey's going to want to be careful with him. The pitch grooves in and Kurowski nails it.
Oh dear. There goes number 21.
The Cardinals leading 3-2 going into the bottom of the 12

The stadium electric as Jack steps in, his left leg blood He takes an inside pitch at the knees. Bastards! Here comes the next one. WHACK - He singles hard up the middle, nearly takes the pitcher's head off.
He rounds hard, returns to the bag. Reiser stepping up to the plate as Musial holds Jack on at first. Jack in a fur
I don't care what happens, I don't care what kind of play it is, when I get to second I'm gonna knock someone into centerfield. YELLOW REV 4-24-12 107.

(glances at blood) I don't blame you, man, you got every right. Jack running on the pitch. Reiser bunts. The play is to first. Reiser is out and Jack slides safe into second. SCHOENDIENST has the sense to vacate before he gets there
Bouncing up and down, wearing that badge of potential violence and action. The crowd buzzing, the electricity practically hits you in the face. Jack's going to score.
Coming up out of his seat along with the fans around him.
Walker at bat. Jack steps out, checks on MARION the shortstop. He takes another step out, looks to Schoendien

(over it all)  Munger sets. Robbie back and forth  off second. The third bag clearly  in his sights. Oh, and Munger  deals a pick off throw to Marion at  second and Robinson is out!  Marion breaks for the bag and Munger turns and fires a  strike. Marion brings down the tag -- Out!  He is and he knows it. The crowd stunned into silence. Ja frozen a moment, head down, furious with himself. Low.
The Cardinals pick up a game. It  was one of those plays where you do or you don't and Jackie didn't.
Jack on his stomach as STITCHES are sewn into his leg. REPORTERS in front of him.
Did he spike you on purpose? YELLOW REV 4-24-12 107A.
You saw the play. I had my foot  inside the bag. He was out by a  mile. But he kept coming.
Slaughter said it was an accident.
What are you asking me for then?
Are you calling Slaughter a liar? CHERRY REV 6-11-12 108. This guy's a real jerk. Rickey arrives, a BASEBALL in han

Get out. Let me talk to my first baseman. Go. He's getting stitched up for Pete's sake. The reporters move off for other interviews. Reporter Two hesitant to let it go, finally drifts off. Rickey watches
Sticking up for yourself is what you'd expect of any man. Some find it galling to see it in a Negro.
I'm sorry, Mr. Rickey.
Sorry? Sorry for what?
I lost my cool out there. It probably cost us the game.
I told you, Jackie, all the best base runners get caught sometimes.
I wasn't thinking. Rickey pulls up a chair sits across from him, leans in.
Do you know what I saw this morning? I was passing a sandlot and a little white boy was up to bat. You know what he was doing?
Sitting on a fastball?
He was pretending he was you.  Wiping his hands on his pants,  swinging with his arms outstretched  like you do. A little white boy  pretending he was a black man.
The two men, who have done so much, looking each other ov
Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?
We had victory over fascism in Germany; it's time for victory over racism at home.
Why are you doing this? Come on now. A long moment between them. Finally, Rickey looks away.

I love this game. I love baseball. I've given my life to it. Forty odd years ago I was a player coach at Ohio Wesleyan University. We had a Negro catcher, best hitter on the team. Charley Thomas. Rickey starts slowly rubbing the baseball in his hands.

A fine young man. I saw him laid low. Broken because of the color of his skin and I didn't do enough to help. I told myself I did, but I didn't. The game I loved had something unfair at the heart of it. I ignored it. But a time came when I could no longer do that.
You let me love baseball again. Thank you. Jack's eyes gentle on Rickey's.
You're welcome. GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 110. Rickey fighting back tears now, retreats to his more  confident self.

You're a force of nature, Jackie, you've complicated everything but yourself. You're changing the world, and refusing to let it change you. I for one am in awe. Jack reaches, takes the baseball from him. A beat as they consider each other. Finally, a promise...
I won't get picked off second base again. Not this year.
It's early. Rachel watches from bed as Jack finishes packing. She looks sad. Jack looks into the cradle at Jackie Jr..
It's pop's last long road trip of the year, little man.
Careful you don't wake him.
I know. I won't.
You okay?
I don't like seeing you leave, that's all. He looks at her a beat, resumes packing...
I'll be home in a week.
Eleven days. That's a long time  without you.  He doesn't answer, packs away. Finally:
Try not to lunge at the plate.
Seriously?
That's why they're throwing the fastballs inside. He looks at her, a little shocked. DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 112.
Fight those inside fastballs off, foul them back. Sooner or later they won't be able to help but throw a curve. He steps to the bed, leans over her.
And what'll happen then? She clucks a 'hit' sound, makes an 'ahhhhhh' crowd sound.
We win enough of these next games and we'll bring home the pennant.
Pennant? Where are we going to put a pennant? All these baby diapers hanging everywhere. Jack looks around the room, at the diapers hanging.
We got room right over there. Between number one and number two. She mock grimaces at his bad joke.
Win one if you have to, but bring yourself home; that'll be plenty. They kiss.
Rae, you're in my heart.
Promise me you'll come home. That you'll always come home. As he looks at all he loves in the world...
I promise.
Jack exits MacDonough Street apartment building and makes way down the street.
A CARDINAL RUNNER on second. Jackie holding another RUNNE on first as the St. Louis crowd ROARS.

2 on 2 out for the Cardinals in the  eighth. Anxious moments now as  they've cut the Dodger lead to 2.  Nippy Jones up. Musial taking his  place on deck. Jones likes to  punch that ball when he swings.  Insert: September 13, 1947. Casey on the mound receives the ball. Pounds his glove.
Come on, Casey, get him out! Pitch that ball!
The outfield is deep, shaded toward  left. Robinson holding the runner  on first. Here comes Casey with  the pitch --  Jones swings, pops it up.
It's popped up foul toward first.  Should be out of play. But here  comes Robinson, he's coming hard --

Jack chasing down the foul, headed right for the open ste of his own dugout. He never considers the peril as he CATCHES THE BALL and his left foot comes down onto nothin BRANCA LEAPS forward, tackles Jack back onto the infield.
He's got it! And one of the Dodgers has him!

The Dodgers closing in on the  Pennant as they'll leave St. Louis  for Cincinnati and a three game  series with the Reds.  Jack sits in his grass stained pants after the game. Most the guys are in the shower. Branca, a towel around his waist, is headed there himself. The sight of Jack stops h
Can I ask you something, Jackie? How come you never shower until everyone else is done? Jack just stares at him. Branca won't let it drop.
You shy or something?
I don't want to make anyone uncomfortable. BUFF REV 5-29-12 116.
We're a team. On a hot streak. Half the wins on account of you. You're the bravest guy I ever saw. You're leading us and you're afraid to take a shower? A beat as Jack considers him. Stone-faced.
C'mon. Take a shower with me.
Hey, I don't mean it like that.

The Dodgers showering, guys chattering. Suddenly, there's Branca and Jack at the shower entrance. All eyes look ove Branca enters. Then Jack. A beat and everyone goes back t getting clean. It's no big deal. Except... Dixie Walker looks to the floor, shakes his head. Finally quietly, he leaves. Who's the loneliest man on the team n
As the phone rings, Rickey grabs it. On edge. INSERT: September 16, 1947
Rickey here.
On a payphone in the CROSLEY FIELD CONCOURSE.
We did it, Boss! We did it! We swept Cincinnati! That puts us  seven games up.  Joyous, Rickey grabs a sheet showing the NL standings.

And eliminates the Giants and  Boston. He puts an a X' through Boston and the Giants. The rest o the NL are already crossed out. Only the Cardinals remain At the same time, Parrott X's the same out on his noteboo DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 117.
We'd have to lose nearly every game for the Cardinals to catch us now. One more win may do it. Who's pitching tomorrow for the Pirates?
Ostermueller.

Rachel walks pushing Jackie Junior in his stroller. As sh moves, the RADIO BROADCAST of the Dodgers' game can be he from one house to the next. In a gap, a passing car picks up and we hear it from the window. Then another house.
A very big game today here in Pittsburgh. A win and the Dodgers will have clinched the National League Pennant.
Branch Rickey alone in the stadium. The field empty as he listens to the call of the game over the PA.
Fritz Ostermueller on the mound. He's 12 and 8 on the season.
INSERT: September 17, 1947. Pittsburgh. Ostermueller on the rubber. Staring in at Jack.
You don't belong! You'll never belong! Jack waits. Ostermueller pitches.
Here comes the pitch and Robinson takes outside. Ball one.
Listening as -- DBL. WHITE REV 6-28-12 117A.
Ostermueller winds and throws, low and away ball two. Fritz seems to be pitching around Jackie. Or trying to get him to chase.
Come on. Throw him a strike.
Shakes off one sign, then nods at the next. Throws the ba well outside. Another pitch outside. aBall Three!a
3 and 0 now. Robinson waiting on something he can swing on. As catcher Kluttz throws it back...
Give me something I can hit!
What are you afraid of?
You want it?!
Careful what you wish for boy... Ostermueller nods at the sign. Jack about to slay the dra as the pitch comes in - WHACK! The ball is going for a ri
That is a deep fly ball to left. Kiner on his horse, but I don't think he'll get there.
Rickey standing, looking up like he can see it.
Back, back, back and oh doctor! Robinson got his pitch!
The ball sails out: HOME RUN! Ostermueller hangs his head DBL. WHITE REV 6-28-12 117B.
Rachel listening, smiling as CHEERS sound from outside th apartment. We hear the sound of car horns on the street.

He runs toward first and we run with him. The smile start somewhere in his body. His heart most likely. By the time it reaches his face, his joy has erupted. The weight of t world starting to drop. TAN REV 6-25-12 118.
Kirby Higbe who watches Robinson round the bases in disgu
Pittsburgh...
Nears second on his home run trot. Even the Pittsburgh cr starting to applaud him.
Rickey absorbing the moment. It's almost too much.
Rounding second and headed for third. The weight of the world somehow lifting. They gave him one he could hit.
We're tight on Jack's back as he heads for home at Forbes Field. 90 feet away... 75...
Finally inspired to type: T-h-a-n-k y-o-u, J-a-c-k-i-e.
Nearing home. About to step on the plate. He closes his eyes as well and --
Rachel all alone on the sidewalk looking up and down the  street. And suddenly there he is... Jack, scooting betwee two cars, hurrying to her. And they're in each others arm
I'm home.
Safe.
The baby's sleeping so don't you  make a sound.  He makes to button his lips.

Stay just like that.  She kisses him. And kisses him. And he kisses her back. A they finally head inside, we let them go. And as we're le looking down the street, a crawl begins:  BLUE REV 4-07-12 120. Branch Rickey was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1967.  Pee Wee Reese was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1984. Bobby Bragan retired the following year and became a mana in the Dodger minor leagues. He is credited with mentorin several African American minor league players. Wendell Smith became the first African-American sportswri to join the Baseball Writers Association in 1948. Ben Chapman was fired in 1948 and never managed again. Eddie Stanky went on to manage the St. Louis Cardinals, t Chicago White Sox and the Texas Rangers.  Ralph Branca lives and works in Rye, New York.  Dixie Walker was traded the following season to Pittsburg Ed Charles grew up to become a professional baseball play He won the World Series in 1969 with the Miracle Mets. Rachel Robinson splits her time between Connecticut and Manhattan where she runs the Jackie Robinson Foundation. Jackie Robinson was named Major League Rookie of the Year 1947. He won the World Series in 1955 against the New Yor Yankees, stealing home in Game One. He was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962.  We end on a montage of Jackie Robinson Day in present tim Every year in April, all MLB players wear the number 42 a reminder of Jackie's accomplishments on and off the field The number 42 is the only number retired by all of baseba We see 42s leaving their dugouts, 42s at bat, 42s in the field, 42s signing autographs, 42s stealing bases, 42s li up for the National Anthem. FREEZE FRAME on a 42. The End.
